scenes.location: OLD OFFICE, (SANTA BARBARA, CA) SANTA BARBARA, CA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is California Spanish, thick walls, arches, and light spills in from a mission window. But we don't have any sense of place just yet. At first there are just details.

dialogues.speaker: TYPEWRITER KEYS
dialogues.text: of an old Underwood upright, well-worn and ancient. A woman's fingertips with red nail polish are placed on the keys. They wiggle.

dialogues.speaker: PIPE IN ASHTRAY
dialogues.text: Smoke curls.   A man's hand picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S HAT AND COAT
dialogues.text: on a coat rack.

dialogues.speaker: WASTE BASKET
dialogues.text: Overflowing with crunched-up paper.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: lies on a couch near the window. He stands up suddenly and looks out the window. AL STUMP, 40, is sharply dressed -- tie, dress shirt, cufflinks. He's staring at something.

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD BELOW
dialogues.text: in high heels crosses the courtyard. She glances up toward Stump, then quickly turns away and disappears.

dialogues.speaker: STUMP
dialogues.text: He sighs, and turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The muse has   not descended, Lucille. (off   her silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The muse has   not descended. (off   her silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it,   Lucille, you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: LUCILLE
dialogues.text: The woman at the typewriter, a 50-year old steno/secre- tary, responds calmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The muse has not descended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! The muse has left me stranded here like a beached whale -- only one phrase, one word, from finishing the greatest essay I've ever written! One word, the right word -- Flaubert called it 'le mot juste' -- I ever tell you that? Lucille is a longsuffering saint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Le mot juste' -- the exact right word the writer needs to tell his story. Yessir, you've mentioned it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hemingway, Faulkner, Joyce -- they all searched for 'le mot juste' until they cried, until they bled...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this essay about again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean what is it really about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said it was about the quote unquote primal issues of survival, man against nature, etcetera -- that's what you said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohyeah... so... we end the essay with...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dictating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'The tarpon leaps shimmering into the late cross light of the keys, a primeval moment frozen in... (hesitates)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... frozen in'... Lucille types it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shimmering tarpon -- very good, Mr. Stump... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... 'frozen in' what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Lucille, that's what the Muse will tell me if she ever descends. (considering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... 'frozen in'... The PHONE RINGS -- Lucille answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? Yes? Just a minute, I'll see if he's available. (covers phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your wife -- are you and she speaking again? Stump's cavalier attitude stops cold.     He starts to re for the phone, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno.   How does she sound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask me to interpret. Stump is suddenly a nervous wreck.     He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her... tell her... I'll talk... no... tell her I'm out -- I'll call her later... (serious, dark)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently he's out, Mrs. Stump -- I'll have him call you back. She hangs up.    The mood has shifted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about 'le mot juste,' Mr. Stump?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck 'le mot juste,' Lucille! Finish the damn thing yourself. 'The primeval moment is frozen in' whatever the hell you want it to be. Did you know that James Joyce let his secretary -- none other than Samuel Beckett -- revise and edit Molly's solliloquy in Ulysses? You're my Beckett -- I give you 'le mot juste!' Just get the damn thing in the mail so I can get paid. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Problems with the Mrs.? Stump reaches for a beat-up pogo stick which leans agains the wall in his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.    I need a drink. He grabs his hat and coat and we begin hearing the number one hit song of 1960, PERCY FAITH'S schmaltzy recording o "A Summer Place."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump pogo sticks down the sidewalk, tipping his hat to pedestrians. They're not alarmed. He's the town eccentric. He pogos across a street and towards --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A watering hole like a million others.   He pogo sticks right in the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A classic city bar, a hangout for drunks, philosophers, and especially sportswriters and journalists. Our man hops off his pogo stick -- nobody even notices, and joins his cronies, five sportswriters full of dogmati opinions on every subject known to man. FRANK, a sportswriter, is at the jukebox feeding quarters He looks up routinely, they're all regulars here. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Stumpy... Stump addresses the sportswriters at the table as if they were a small audience in a lounge. STUMP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, awright... how do you get five old ladies to say 'fuck?' CRONIES (stumped)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, I dunno, how? Etc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yell 'bingo.' Stump laughs. The others groan. REYNALDO, 40's, black, speaks up. He's one of the regulars. REYNALDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I got one -- (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drunk is taking a piss in front of a bar, a bus drives by, real fast right along the curb, and knocks his thing off. Drunk picks up his thing, puts it in his pocket, goes into a bar, reaches into his pocket and puts his thing on the bar. 'Look't that,' he says, 'bus knocked my thing off.' Bartender says, 'that ain't your thing -- that's a cigar butt.' (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drunk reaches into his other pocket and slaps another thing on the bar. 'There,' he says, 'bus knocked my thing off.' Bartender says, 'you're drunk and that ain't your thing either. That's another cigar butt.' (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drunk looks down at both cigar butts and back up at the bartender and says, 'God damn it, I mushta smoked my dick.' Everyone roars, even Stump. But Frank, as usual, is hyper serious and never quite gets into the revelry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amidst this levity, gentlemen, I have some real concerns. Mark my words, people will look back on this year and say that 1960 was the year that Western Civilization began its downward trajectory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to get laid, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys, guys, c'mon... do you really think things are as good as they used to be? You think Jack Kennedy is qualified to be President?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kennedy may not be qualified, but -- Jackie's a babe -- and that's good enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're a happily married couple and that oughta stand for something these days... Every man nods in solemn agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking of being happily married, Al, are you and your old lady still having problems?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, the wife and I are all patched up -- doin' fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to hear... awright... way to go, Stumpy... (Etc.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean look at us -- we call ourselves writers but we just watch ballgames and get drunk a lot. You call that writing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the department store of life, sports is the toy department -- so what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, besides, Alan here's writing a serious novel, aren't ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well I haven't started yet but I'm gonna. I've been busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys are pathetic. Ya write for one reason -- a paycheck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More art was created for money than for passion. Take your platitudes and shove 'em, Frank. I'm gonna write a novel too, someday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cynically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Great American Novel, I suppose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could come from my pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a barbershop writer, Al -- you write sugar-coated pieces for guys to skim when they're waiting for a haircut!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, that's it! Let's go! Settle this right here! Stump raises his fists as if to fight; Frank responds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! A scuffle breaks out, a lot of posturing, feinting, but they're all too chicken to do anything. Nobody wants to fight. A PHONE RINGS at the bar. The bartender answers the phone, shouts at the obnoxious sportwriters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump!   For you. Stump goes to the phone, interrupting his own "fight."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Frank)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone call saved your ass. Stump grabs the phone, covering an ear to hear better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... yeah... who?... no... you're kidding?... when? Stump hangs up the phone and turns. His face registers shock, or more precisely, bewilderment and wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... (as they ignore him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! They do, and give Stump their ruffled attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb wants to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty Cobb!    How many Cobbs are there?! This news instantly sobers the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty Cobb?   I thought he was dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. He said he wants to tell me the real story of his life before he croaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were just talking to Ty Cobb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Georgia Peach himself. This impresses the hell out of everyone in the room. Stump is still a little dazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say Cobb is crazy. The meanest sonofabitch who ever lived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard he killed a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe so, but -- he was the greatest baseball player of them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, the best, no one close, etc... Frank suddenly is cautionary, concerned, paternal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Al, be careful --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't gettin' my ass shot, don't worry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not that -- the story. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is like Ivan the Terrible inviting somebody into the Czar's palace before he died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except Ivan was a nicer guy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned, earnest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let Cobb bullshit you. This is your shot. This is all our shot. (as cronies agree)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When does he want to see you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al Stump sits alone in the theater, except for a teenaged boy sweeping the aisles, who stops to watch the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gathered all the film footage that existed on Cobb -- which wasn't much -- and rented the local theater for the afternoon... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, too, had thought that the great Ty Cobb had been dead for awhile...

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN
dialogues.text: The screen fills with (B&W) Movietone Newsreel footag Ty Cobb, complete with overly sincere NARRATION and MUSIC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This 1905 cameo of an 18-year-old youth shows a peaches-and-cream complexion and the piercing eyes of a lad who would become, etc... Onscreen (B&W) -- Cobb as a young ballplayer followed images of Cobb's famous batting stance, Cobb clowning, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His reputation as being difficult at best, psychotic at worst, preceded him. But if there was one thing I knew after all my years as a journalist covering politicians, celebrities, and sports heroes, it was this --

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Onscreen (B&W) -- Cobb with children, Cobb with celeb ties, Cobb in a parade honoring him, and always, Cobb's dashing, swashbuckling style of play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 'facts' -- and public perception of those 'facts' -- frequently bear little resemblance. Onscreen (B&W) -- Cobb in action -- His demon fury gi way to the fierce joy of his playing. He slashes a ball up the alley, turns first and never hesitates at second, and as the relay comes into third --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing was beyond argument -- he was the most brilliant athlete of his time... perhaps of any time. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was determined to find out who was the real Ty Cobb. Cobb slides with spikes high and a cloud of dust. There is something thrilling and terrifying in the image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump's car, a late model Buick, moves across the stunnin grasslands at the western base of the Sierra Nevadas. We begin hearing his voice, then see him inside the car driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump's car heads up into the darkening mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said Cobb owned property all over the country, but in recent years had been staying in his hunting lodge at Lake Tahoe in the Sierra Nevadas.

dialogues.speaker: LONE PAIR OF HEADLIGHTS
dialogues.text: moving up into the Sierras, into rugged terrain and thick forests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump straining to see the road, a bit wary of this drive

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving into the Sierras at night with winter coming on wasn't the smartest decision I'd ever made but it seemed better than being late for my first meeting with Cobb. First drops of rain begin hitting the windshield -- Stump hits the wiper button and the floppy blades begin ineffectively wiping the windshield. Stump struggles with his vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dismal, wet and obscured view of the mountain road, climbing higher into the Sierras. A small roadside gas station comes INTO VIEW, and -- Stump pulls his car into the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump gets out, blows on his hands. It's cold, and a man comes out, the gas station owner, JONAH, 55. The man services the car throughout the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fill it up and replace the wiper blades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colder than a witch's tit, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just starting. We got three- four feet of snow another thousand feet up. Where ya going? Skiing? I hate skiing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I'm going to meet Ty Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb?! He stopped here for gas once, I asked him for an autograph for my boy and he told me to shove it where the sun don't shine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear he's got a way with kids...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump heads to a pay phone as the attendant replaces the wiper blades. Stump's breath hangs heavy in the air. It's cold. Freezing. He drops a set of coins in the call box. He blows on his hands and pulls up his collar -- he wasn't prepared for the weather to be this cold. He comes to life when he hears a voice on the other end -- a voice we never hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, baby, it's me... (beat) Al... your husband... (beat) I'm up in the woods somewhere on assignment... (beat) Listen, sweetheart, listen -- nobody can love you the way I love you and I want you to take me back. I made a mistake. (listens) Okay, lots of mistakes. I know I'm not worthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a CLICK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey?   Sweetheart?   Baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flicks the receiver hook several times.       She's go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAIN POUNDS down as the car climbs to higher elevation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump struggles with a map under the dome light as he drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump's car passes a sign that tells all:    DONNER PASS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I confess I was looking forward to seeing Cobb and being near his brilliance. My own life seemed on hold, somehow. Everyday churning out the same old articles, drinking at 4 in the afternoon with the same old guys, the same old excuses for not writing a novel, the same old confused marriages that we all needed and were trying to get out of at the same time... Cobb was a god whose brilliance, however difficult, could rub off on me. His problems were different than mine...

dialogues.speaker: STUMP'S CAR
dialogues.text: which pulls off the road and heads up a small mountain road among snow-covered pines. A row of mailboxes catches Stump's attention, and he pulls over to review the names with a flashlight. He lights his way across the names of a dozen boxes -- nothing, until: The last box, enormously oversized, bears the name "COBB.

dialogues.speaker: STUMP
dialogues.text: He smiles.    Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: His car heads up a mountain road a final hundred yards, comes around a bend in the trees and there it is --

dialogues.speaker: HUGE MOUNTAIN LODGE
dialogues.text: In the grand style but, like the mailbox, grotesquely oversized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump parks and approaches somewhat warily. The sound of BREAKING GLASS and SHOUTING voices. Stump hurries to the door to escape the rain and finds refuge under the eave. The noise is frightening from that close. He stands unsurely -- does he knock? When -- The door is thrown open -- a black man, WILLIE, 40, with a suitcase stands wildly upset, screaming back into the house. WILLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Mr. Cobb, I have too much dignity to spend another moment with you. I hope you die before the sun comes up and may you rot in hell! The man whirls and is shocked to see Stump standing there with his own suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a writer. WILLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean he actually found somebody to take the job? Willie bursts out into crazed laughter, as if the world of Cobb was finally too absurd. Cobb and a writer? In this weather? In any weather? And the man walks through the rain, laughing, heading on foot down off the mountain as Stump just stares. Stump turns and steps into the open doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump in the front door -- The place is enormous and barely lit. Taxidermied game hangs on the wall. Stump is terrified. A MAN is sitting in an overstuffed chair reading a news- paper. Dressed in a business suit and tie, he seems oblivious to the surrounding chaos. He also seems out of place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cobb? The man looks at Stump and points upstairs without speaking. More CRASHING sounds from upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cobb? The silence is shattered by a SCRATCH, then VIOLIN MUSIC from upstairs. STATIC suggests a record is playing.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRS
dialogues.text: Stump climbs the stairs with caution -- Until he's just outside the half open door from which light spills. He hesitates...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?   Mr. Cobb? A GUNSHOT RINGS OUT -- Ripping through the door.       St is terrified -- he gasps for air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, Mr. Cobb, but I don't need this job that bad. Stump turns and creeps back toward the stairs, but -- ANOTHER GUNSHOT RINGS OUT -- SHATTERING a hanging LAMP. Stump freeses one more time.     Silence.   Then the voice --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Stump -- you do need this job that bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Now come in here and meet the great Ty Cobb. (calmly) I won't hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump breathes deeply and steps into the doorway -- He does it as if there's no choice, accepting his fate. And sees:

dialogues.speaker: TY COBB
dialogues.text: Lying in bed in a robe. Unshaven. Bottles of booze and food everywhere. And bottles of pills sit on every surface. Two hunting dogs sit on the bed with him. A small record player sits next to he bed. A record spins, filling the room with FRITZ KREISLER VIOLIN SOLOS. He places the gun on      his night table, knocking pills bottles to the floor      with a crash he barely notices. When he speaks it is      without a snarl, without threat simply, even sweetly,      he says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the violin -- Fritz Kreisler. I'm a great admirer of his. I'm also a great admirer of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you are a hopeless romantic and only a moderate success.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I am the most successful sportswriter in America and not merely a 'moderate success.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. (beat) Give me those pills over there.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Stump retrieves some pills that Cobb is pointing towards. Cobb washes down a handful of pills with a bottle of Scotch. Momentarily revitalized, Cobb hands Stump a folded letter which Stump opens to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's an invitation to a testimonial dinner at the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, New York. You're taking me there -- when is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the letter) A few weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the great ones will be there -- The great Mickey Cochrane will be there! Hornsby, Sisler, Ott, the Waner Brothers... we used to have some parties, Stump, I'll tell ya that right now... (beat) We can't forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me closely, Al... (with utmost sincerity) Lie after lie has been written about me -- my whole life I've been misunderstood. (beat) You're gonna tell the real story of Ty Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the 'real' story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb climbs slowly out of bed.     His words are reasoned and not without passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why you're here. (beat) See, there's two kinds of writers. The kind that spin endless yarns about small subjects... that's you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Or... there's the kind with one great subject that consumes them forever. (beat) That could be you. Because I am that subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb hobbles to a table in front of a window. The table is covered with pills, bottles, needles, and booze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly bellowing) Jameson! Get your ass up here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb grabs another bottle of booze and swigs deeply, liquor spilling over him. Then, suddenly, he holds up his hand. A calm comes over him as -- He stares out the window into the snowy woods.       His rage has quickly turned into a quiet, intense, unsettling focus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmmmm...

dialogues.speaker: WOODS IN MOONLIGHT
dialogues.text: near the lodge. A bank of snow -- and a large buck moves INTO VIEW.

dialogues.speaker: COBB'S FACE
dialogues.text: His eyes light.     A flare in his nostrils.    A twitch. utter calm.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Jameson, the man in the suit, arrives and stands in the back of the room. He takes notes when Cobb speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb continues staring out the window at the buck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a small oil company near Bakersfield called Honolulu Oil, sitting near the Elk Hills Reserve... (beat) I want you to buy all the stock you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honolulu Oil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getty is expanding in the west, looking for companies like that. I got a hunch... (beat) Stumpy, c'mere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb picks up the revolver and holds it lovingly. Stump crosses and stands behind Cobb, sharing the view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can take that buck.     What'ya think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a pistol? No way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb smiles and loads the revolver.       He pushes the w which swings slowly open.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK IN MOONLIGHT
dialogues.text: searches for leaves to eat in the snow.          Serene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jameson) There's a board meeting of Coca-Cola in Georgia next week. Call them up and tell them I can't make it for medical -- (correcting himself) -- personal -- reasons... (beat) ... and sell all the 3-M stock we got.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: raises the gun -- he wobbles badly and steadies himself. The gun shakes. Then steadies. Stump stands over his shoulder watching the bizarre action.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK RAISES ITS HEAD
dialogues.text: Just as... KABLAM!   The REVOLVER FIRES with a violent kick. The buck spins and runs back into the woods, kicking snow and disappearing in the brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like hell you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right behind the ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jameson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Mr. Cobb said he got him, then he got him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no vision, Stump. A writer without vision is a waste of my time. I think I picked the wrong man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb stumbles back into bed, somewhat exhausted by the ordeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I think I better get back to San Francisco before the storm hits. I'll take care of these transactions, Mr. Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Jameson exits the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'll be leaving as well, sir, since you think I'm the wrong man for the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Stump -- we both know that I'm your meal ticket. (beat) We need each other. (smiles) And we start in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb reaches over and defiantly turns UP the MUSIC so that the room is overwhelmed with Kreisler's violin. Stump stares back at this decrepit, overpowering figure. Cobb gradually slips into sleep, buried in the music, the booze, the pills, the pain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. The morning mist hangs thick over a snowbank in the woods A rabbit scurries across the snow, some quail are flushed PAN ACROSS the landscape REVEALS the lodge.    Smoke curl from the chimney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump sits hunkered over a tiny portable typewriter on the kitchen table. Cobb mixes a bourbon with orange juice to wash down some more pills, which he takes randomly. A teletype MACHINE sits on a table nearby -- Throughout the scene, a tape CLICKS endlessly out, piling on the floor. Cobb occasionally checks data on the tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready, Mr. Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chapter one, Page one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Know ye that a prince and a great man has fallen this day.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump types it out, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what Robert E. Lee said at the burial of my grandfather who was a Confederate General killed at Fredricksburg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'm taking notes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell no. That's the first line of my autobiography.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't writing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's horseshit. It's a third person comment about someone who's already dead. An autobiography has to be in the first person -- plus it can't come from the other side of the God damn grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My story can come from any damn place I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to mention you can't call yourself 'a prince and great man' -- that's for the world to decide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of a fucking writer you call yourself -- all tied up in rules and regulations. What's the point being a writer if you can't say what you want to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not treating me like a writer -- you're treating me like a stenographer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLAM! A SHOT RINGS OUT -- Stump types quickly, hunting and pecking with two fingers, reading aloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know ye that a prince and a great man has fallen this day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has a certain ring to it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you might like it. It's yours, a gift from me. (beat) 'Cobb, a prince among men, misunderstood in his genius, as genius always is' - (demands from Stump) This is the second line from what will be the greatest biography of a great man ever written -- type it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb checks the tape and suddenly is deep in thought over some information coming across. Stump types.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem Steel's about to dive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb grabs a phone and dials -- Then barks into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Jameson. Bethlehem's going in the toilet. Dump it all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb slams down the phone, momentarily lost in finance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a stock tip for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... buy Coca-Cola. We're about to go out in cans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coke in cans?    I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb just stares back in disdain.      Then, suddenly -- Cobb starts coughing terribly. He clutches his torso as if it were about to fall into pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what's wrong with Ty Cobb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly) Every disease known to man -- I got 'em all! And they'll never get me in a hospital -- never! (beat) My heart leaks -- the doctors who are nothin' but a buncha hacksaw artists give me Digoxin to keep it pumping...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb grabs a bottle of Digoxin pills and flings it across the room in a rage. He flings bottles of pills as he recites his ailments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They give me Darvon for the cancer in my back, they give me Tace for something eatin' up my stomach, Fleets Compound for an infection in my bowels, Librium for my tension, insulin for my diabetes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb grabs a hypodermic needle and awkwardly pours from a bottle into the chamber. Insulin spills as he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' insulin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jams the needle wildly into his arm without hesitation

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He takes a deep breath as if the drug has produced an immediate relief from pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if all that wasn't enough, it's been two years since I got my pecker in the air... (beat) The South may not rise again but my dick will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barks) I ain't here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (answering the phone) Cobb's residence... hello. (beat) He's not here -- who's calling? Ernie? Ernie who? (his face drops) My God... (to Cobb) It's Ernest Hemingway... for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him to go to hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump covers the receiver nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus  Christ, Ty, this is the great  American writer -- this is the  man who inspired me to become  a writer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him to go to hell anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him and me used to be pals but we went on a hunting trip once and he hired a shitty guide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it? You didn't like a guide he hired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb looks at Stump with a fierceness that is so over- whelming, so physical, that Stump melts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell him to go fuck himself or I'll kick your Yankee ass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump is terrified.    He reluctantly uncovers the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hemingway? Mr. Cobb says... to go to hell. (awkwardly) By the way I'm a big fan of yours --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLICK, a hang up. Cobb settles into a chair, letting the drugs and pills and booze work their way into his thick body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hemingway isn't a bullfighter -- he wrote about bullfighting. What the hell is that?! (beat) Bullshit... Damn painkillers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb rubs his head -- The drugs are taking effect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty, you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll pass... (increasingly woozy) Stumpy, listen to me -- you know what I need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a woman. (muttering to sleep) A woman is definitely what I need...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And Cobb drifts to sleep in his chair, momentarily overcome with painkillers. Stump stares at the sleeping volcano of a man, and when Cobb starts snoring heavily, he rises, pulls on a coat, scarf, and hat, and heads out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow flurries greet Stump as he heads outside, and darkness is falling. He takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't be around the man for long without needing a break, which his painkillers gracefully provided. (beat) My sanity would soon depend upon a frequent breath of fresh air, a walk in the woods -- any escape from what one sportswriter had called 'Cobb's brooding soul that bubbled with violence.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump lights a pipe as he walks up a trail, away from the lodge, toward a ridge, all covered with snow. The flurries of snow are getting thicker now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew most of the Cobb stories -- first man elected to the Hall of Fame, ahead of the incomparable Babe Ruth. Statistics that haven't been approached in three-quarters of a century.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump stops at the ridge and looks down at the partially frozen Lake Tahoe in the lingering light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'd known boxing champions and football players -- they were gentle souls outside the arena. (beat) How much of Cobb was an act, a lifetime of theatrical intimidation to preserve his own legend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Legends grow in time. Tough guys are tougher, women more beautiful, routine acts of self-preservation become heroic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump continues walking down a crest of snow, through a stand of snow-covered pines. The light is dark, purple, eerie, and Stump is lost in thought, until, suddenly, he sees: A trail of blood in the snow. He follows it down a slope, past a tree, growing deeper, thicker. And there it is -- The buck lies dead in the snow in a pool of blood. Stump stops in fear, then approaches, leans down and examines --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The buck's head has a hole blasted behind the ear. Stump rises quickly to his feet and looks around. The woods are silent. Snow falls from a branch. And... He hurries back through the woods up the ridge, momen- tarily lost as the snow swirls, he finally spots the lodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump bursts into the lodge as the brewing storm blows in. Cobb is standing there in a hunting jacket, high laced boots, a hat, with a suitcase. He holds a paper bag wrapped in twine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to Reno.   I want a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a blizzard out there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When a man wants a woman, a man wants a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just put on some soup, build a fire, and we can work on the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How cozy. (holds up the paper bag) I got 25 thousand in cash and negotiable securities in here. Don't let it out of your sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Ty, the roads are impassable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lead, I'll follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not driving in this stuff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a woman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blizzard -- two cars ease down an ice-covered road in an increasingly horrendous snowstorm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump is terrified, straining to see through the flurries which grow thicker by the second. He keeps checking his rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb at the wheel of a huge, black, Chrysler Imperial. He looks possessed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb at the wheel -- A madman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call that driving, Alice?! My sister can drive faster than that! Step on it!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He grabs a bottle of bourbon on the seat and chugs it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A treacherous cliff drops quickly away from the road, certain death protected by an inadequate guardrail. Into a blizzard, increasingly out of control, the cars slip and slide and skid down the mountain. Cobb leans on his HORN -- HONK, HONK, HONK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump struggles to hang on as the car fishtails on the edge of losing control. He keeps glancing at Cobb who continues screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get off the road -- ya can't drive any faster?! Move it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump is caught between fear and rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you! I ain't dying in this God damn ice cube!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb's eyes flare -- The WIND roars, the blizzard beats against the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) The man drives like an old woman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb steps on the gas -- His car pulls out into the oncoming lane and accelerates to pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb's car passes Stump's car down the steep grade. Insane, impossible, suicidal -- not another car on the road, the highway closed, barely visible... and here comes Cobb. Stump stares in disbelief as he clings to the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb waves his fist as he speeds past --

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: He laughs, cackling madly at Stump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drive, motherfucker, drive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black Chrysler rushes down the mountain into the raging storm.

dialogues.speaker: STUMP
dialogues.text: struggles to see through the windshield -- snow is swirling everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb's car disappears into the blizzard, fishtailing as it goes.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: STUMP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump's car creeps along the edge of a deep ravine that plunges to a raging, icy river. The car fishtails, straightens, and continues on, slowly groping down the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: STUMP
dialogues.text: Sheer terror. It takes his full powers of concentration to keep the car on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a goner, Al, save your own God damn ass...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His car lights reveal tire tracks in the snowdrifts on the highway. The tracks skid wildly, clearly out of control, and head straight off the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump stops his car and gets out -- He hurries to the edge of the road where the bank drops away quickly.

dialogues.speaker: COBB'S CAR
dialogues.text: lies nose down at the bottom of a snow-filled ravine, thirty feet away. The tail lights are still on. The car is totalled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump plows his way on foot down the embankment, fighting bad footing and snowdrifts, until -- He arrives at the car -- Surely nobody could survive this. With difficulty, he makes his way to the back door of the huge car and wrestles it open. Stump sticks the top half of his body into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb lies upside down, ass in the air, his face buried under the dash of the car. There's blood on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about fucking time you got here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb struggles to right himself, twisting and turning free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't call it living but it'll do. Help me outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump helps Cobb back out of the car.    It is an awkward clumsy, difficult task.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's blood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course there's blood! I just put my head through the windshield of a car, what the hell ya think, ya big fucking jerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty Cobb can't die like this! They'll bury me and nobody'll know who it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump drags Cobb awkwardly through the snowbank back up to the highway. When they get to the edge of the high- way, Cobb stops to stare at the tire tracks leaving the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look't that! No guard rail! I'm suing the State Highway Commission, I'm suing the Governor, I'm suing every God damn body! (outraged) I coulda been killed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it, shut up and get in the car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blizzard swirls around the two men, now at Stump's car on the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme your keys, I'm driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how to get to Reno? Hell, no! I'm driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over my dead body!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb pulls a gun from his overcoat pocket and aims it right at Stump's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You miserable son of a bitch. You coward, you pathetic, frightened, desperate old man -- you can't do anything without that gun and frankly it doesn't impress me to keep flashing it because I know you're not gonna shoot me 'cause you need me worse than I need you. What, you're gonna kill me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb smiles. He loves it when someone stands up to him. He thrives on confrontation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've killed a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, then put me outta my fuckin' misery. I'm freezing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb hands the gun to Stump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here ya go, Stumpy. I like a man who stands up to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump holds the gun awkwardly, not knowing what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now give me the keys.   I'm driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car races down the mountain -- a wild ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb at the wheel is perfectly happy and at peace. Stump, in the passenger's seat, braces himself for certain death COBB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only another hour -- plenty of time to tell you my story before we find us some women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Women?   Plural? COBB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some for you, some for me. We'll have a helluva time. The broads're probably lining up right now, waiting for ol' Ty and his buddy Stump. STUMP (muttering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God... And Cobb launches in as he accelerates down the mountain, every curve risking death. He seems at peace with the world -- in the driver's seat, literally, on the edge of being utterly out of control. COBB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you want to know about my childhood. Writers usually do. STUMP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of this 'know ye that a prince and great man has fallen' stuff -- COBB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My philosophy is simply this   -- Life is too short to be diplomatic. A man's friends shouldn't mind what he does  or says, and those who are not  his friends, well, to hell with  'em. And Cobb drifts into a story of his youth. He's suddenly so relaxed that he pays little attention to the road. COBB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was born in a small town in Georgia, of course... my sweet sister Florence still lives there... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) And I started playing baseball when I was a kid like everybody else only I was better than every- body else. When I was seventeen I started playing for money -- my father didn't approve. (beat) He was a great man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the snow whirls around the car hurtling down the mountain, the snowflakes FILL the SCREEN and turn to confetti as we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 46   EXT. ROYSTON (GEORGIA) - DAY (1900) (B&W) Confetti falls from the sky -- PROFESSOR COBB, 40, Ty's father, waves to the crowd in front of city hall. Signs everywhere declare him to be the newly elected MAYOR COBB A band plays "Sweet Georgia Brown" as the Mayor makes a victory speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was the mayor, they were grooming him for governor, he was a learned man, a professor, and the Head Deacon in the Baptist Church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 47   INT. BAPTIST CHURCH - DAY (B&W) Professor Cobb sings loudly with the Deacons behind the Pastor as the CONGREGATION joins in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings loudly) 'There is a fountain filled with blood, Drawn from Emmanuel's veins...'

dialogues.speaker: TY'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Very young and pretty, singing in the Congregation. And young Ty next to her, also singing at the top of his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother was the most beautiful woman in the county... she married my father when she was twelve which was the way they used to do it. (beat) And she taught me to believe in the hymns we sang... I especially liked the bloody ones... (singing the hymn) 'And sinners plunged beneath that flood, Lose all their guilty stains...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48   EXT. RIVER IN GEORGIA - DAY (B&W) Young Ty Cobb is baptized in the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember after I was baptized and I was walking home with my pals...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49   EXT. TRAIN TRACK IN RURAL GEORGIA - DAY (B&W) Young Ty and three buddies walk along the track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was feeling very Christian, ready to live the good life -- my father didn't drink, smoke, gamble or chase women -- and I wasn't going to either --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys skip rocks and start across a trestle bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... when all of a sudden a train was coming at us.

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN
dialogues.text: headed right for the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There I was, a newly baptized child of God who hadn't hardly sinned, and I was gonna die.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The other other boys leap safely into the river, well ahead of the oncoming train. But young Ty stays on the tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engine bore down on me till I could see the whites of the engineer's eyes -- I was thrilled...

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEER
dialogues.text: He pulls the WHISTLE and screams at the young boy standin defiantly on the track.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG COBB
dialogues.text: His face filled with excitement as the space between him and the engine reduces to nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closer and closer the engine comes -- 50 yards, 25 yards, 10, five, four, three... moments before death -- Young Ty Cobb leaps to safety, flying in front of the engine, out over the water till he splashes, mere milli- seconds before he would have been crushed to death. Young Cobb surfaces in the river and waves his arms in triumph. His pals shriek with delight and embrace him at his courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... it was the greatest thrill in my life not counting the first time I saw a woman naked...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50   SERIES OF SHOTS (B&W) Other trains on other tracks bearing down on young Cobb. In each case -- Young Cobb dances in the track and leaps with grace to safety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I felt protected. By my father, my mother, the baptism, I don't know -- but from that moment on I knew I couldn't be hurt.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: Young Cobb hurtles through the air toward the river, just missing the locomotive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb and Stump continue racing down the mountainside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father died in a terrible accident, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't, really...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you do your research on me before you came up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have time... I mean, I knew the basics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you've read that I'm the meanest bastard of them all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People have said that, yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what people think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why do you care what I write?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am who I tell you I am!   Why are you making things so complicated?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what writers do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well writers oughta make things simple! Everything's complicated enough as it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mutters) Maybe you're right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'm right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump suddenly looks up and shouts in terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A snow-covered truck in the middle of the road, broken down and abandoned, is on top of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Godddddddd!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb spins the wheel -- The car spins out of control, just missing the truck, and hurtling on down the icy highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shout like that, Stumpy -- it just increases my tension. I saw that truck all along -- you think I'm gonna hit a truck when I'm getting close to finding me some women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump is in sheer terror by this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father was murdered, y'know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father was murdered?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean that's the sort of thing you're looking for, isn't it? (beat) Murdered on the balcony of his own house... the house I grew up in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52   EXT. GABLED HOUSE IN GEORGIA - NIGHT (B&W) The head of a horse in f.g., shaking its head, uncomfort- able with the bit in its mouth. In the b.g., the gabled house in the moonlight. A small light spills from a second- floor window onto the balcony. A man on the balcony porch moves toward the window from which light spills. The man pulls up the window and -- KABLAM! A SHOTGUN BLAST rips the silence and darkness. The man falls on his back. KABLAM!   A second SHOTGUN BLAST takes off his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump is stunned by this information as the car careens wildly down the mountainside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father was murdered? How come nobody knows about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The oldtimers in Royston know about it. Nobody else's business. It happened when I was 17, a few days before Detroit called me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this helps explain why -- He catches himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why I'm such a prick? Ha! (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too easy -- you're a better writer than that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was the killer ever caught?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was an arrest, a trial, and an acquittal. Nobody was ever convicted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, don't go sob-sister on me, Stumpy. (beat) The only thing that finally matters is a man's accomplishments and I must say, in all humility, Al, in all humility -- I was the greatest ballplayer of all time. Nobody is even a close second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54   EXT. DETROIT BALL PARK - DETROIT DUGOUT - DAY (c1910 (B&W) A gambling den. Money on the bench. Two men is suits are placing bets, intermingling with the players. A player smokes, another drinks -- this is as far from the anti- septic modern game as can be imagined. Cobb, early 20's, selects his bat, talks to the gambler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Single to left, steal second, steal third, steal home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight to one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten to one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb tosses some money on the pile, and climbs up the dugout steps, shouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 55   EXT. ON-DECK CIRCLE - DAY (B&W) Cobb swings the bat and shouts at the pitcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, greaseball, check your wife -- one of the players is missing!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The pitcher flips Cobb the finger and takes a sign, deliv ering a pitch which is swung on and missed, strike three. Cobb heads to the plate, passing his dejected teammate who has just struck out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell ever signed you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb laughs -- He seems to feed on these exchanges, and he stands in at the plate, addressing the UMPIRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Cyclops, you're missing a good game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Cobb digs in, he reaches into his back pocket and drops something on home plate, in front of the CATCHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here ya go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Catcher holds up a pair of women's panties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your old lady left 'em in my car last night -- I thought you could give 'em back to her.

dialogues.speaker: CATCHER
dialogues.text: He flips his thumb, a sign for the pitcher to deck Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going down, Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pitcher delivers a fastball right at Cobb's head -- He hits the dirt just before the pitch arrives (and this is long before players wore protective headgear). Cobb rises, laughing defiantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the pitcher) That's as hard as you can throw?! Shit, it that was my fastball I'd wear a dress!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Cobb shouts at the shortstop, a large German-America athlete, the great HONUS WAGNER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Wagner! I'd shade me a little up the middle if I was you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wagner doesn't budge, comfortable in his position, not drawn into Cobb's taunts. Stoic, implacable -- far from Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to catcher) You try to take my head off then you throw a sinker away, in and out, same old shit -- sinker away...

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: His chatter stops, his focus is intense and sudden. He holds the bat strangely, with a split grip, a left- handed batter, he dangles the bat almost parallel to the ground. For all his fierceness, there's a delicacy in the way he holds the bat. A baton, a paintbrush, a magic wand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here comes the pitch -- sinker away -- and Cobb unleashes a swing that is at once quick and powerful. He drives the ball to left, the opposite way -- Wagner lunges to his right -- But the ball skips into left. Cobb streaks to first and rounds the base viciously, dari to stretch it into a double but slamming on the brakes an returning to first when the throw rifles into second. Cobb shouts defiantly at the pitcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You God damn coward! You shoulda thrown at me again! You shoulda hit me in the fucking head!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cobb looks down at Wagner who stands implacably at short- stop, a large, powerfully-built man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Krauthead, I'm coming down.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: He just nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pitcher stretches, looks and delivers -- and Cobb breaks for second. The pitch is wide. The Catcher fires. Wagner takes the throw as Cobb arrives in a spikes-up slide. And Wagner swipes a brutal tag in Cobb's face -- his gian ham of a hand in the tiny glove clutching the ball lashes across Cobb's mouth. Blood gushes. The ball pops free. Wagner seems unbothered by the fact that Cobb is safe at second -- he has bloodied Cobb's face. Cobb seems unboth- ered by the fact that his face is a bloody mess -- he has stolen second. Both men seem satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN DUGOUT
dialogues.text: More money is wagered.

dialogues.speaker: PITCHER
dialogues.text: Stretches and delivers -- Cobb takes off for third. throw is high -- he slides in safely.

dialogues.speaker: IN STANDS
dialogues.text: Bets are doubled. The stands are full of wagering. The whole ballpark is like a giant saloon -- drinking, smoking, wagering -- and the game is played by thugs and brigands.

dialogues.speaker: COBB ON THIRD
dialogues.text: Yells at the pitcher and Catcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want in on the action? My mother has a better arm than you! (to the Catcher) I'm coming to you, greaseball! Coming to kick your dago ass!

dialogues.speaker: CATCHER
dialogues.text: steals a glance at Cobb who takes a menacing lead off third. The Catcher gives a signal to the pitcher.

dialogues.speaker: PITCHER
dialogues.text: nods, winds up, and as he does -- Here comes Cobb with a recklessness beyond reason. And as the pitch arrives in the Catcher's hands, the Catcher digs in to take on Cobb -- Cobb slides spikes high, flying above the earth, his back leg slashing his spikes like knives. It is a slide of utter defiance and violence, a slide intended to harm. A vicious collision between Cobb and the catcher -- blood and dust. The ball rolls free. Safe. Cobb and the catcher immediately start punching and in seconds, a brawl breaks out, both benches clearing. As the police rush out to break up the brawl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In those days you didn't hold hands and dance with the men on the other teams. They were the enemy -- you fought with 'em. (beat) And I was the most hated man in baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56   EXT. PHILADELPHIA BALLPARK - DAY (B&W) Cobb enters the stadium through the dugout. The crowd rises to boo Cobb. The boos are overpowering. Cobb warms up in front of the dugout. The boos are deafening. The vindictive threats are ceaseless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a shit, Cobb!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cobb continues warming up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate your guts, Cobb!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb tips his hat and speaks easily to the fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good day to you, too, sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police escort Cobb to right field -- the roar of the vitriolic crowd increases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what it's like to be booed like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb in right with the cops -- the crowd on its feet, booing so loudly that the air is all one giant, wailing moan of hatred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It feels wonderful! They couldn't live without me! They came to the ballpark to see me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57   INT. HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT (B&W) Cobb opens a stack of mail -- a police chief and subor- dinate officers are with him.

dialogues.speaker: MAIL
dialogues.text: Cut-out letters read:    "COBB - YOU'RE DEAD" Cobb puffs on a cigar defiantly as he reads his hate mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty thousand fans trying to kill me everywhere I went!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58   EXT. PHILADELPHIA BALLPARK - DAY       (B&W) Armed police patrol the stands looking for snipers as Cobb plays the game in right field surrounded by police. The booing increases -- fans truly hate him.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved it. Only great men are booed. Captains of industry and presidents. I knew 'em all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59   EXT. WHITE HOUSE (C. 1920)    (B&W)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woodrow Wilson and Cobb have a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woodrow Wilson had the best Scotch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60   INT. WHITE HOUSE STUDY (B&W) Harding, Cobb and others play cards. A lot of money is on the table. And booze. And women that look suspi- ciously like they've been hired. A floozy drapes herself around President Harding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warren Harding had the best broads...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61   INT. WHITE HOUSE STUDY (B&W) A formal portrait with President Calvin Coolidge and Cobb. Coolidge doesn't smile, doesn't seem to do any- thing. Just another portrait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Calvin Coolidge wasn't any damn fun at all...

dialogues.speaker: COBB'S MOUTH
dialogues.text: during the portrait.    We can read his lips as he mouths "fuck you" silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like an out of control bobsled -- Cobb races and Stump hangs on for his life. COBB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After World War Two, General Patton asked me for an autograph -- he said he patterned himself after me! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you getting this? STUMP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll remember. COBB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why aren't you writing?! STUMP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I'm trying to have a good grip on things when this car goes over the next cliff! I ain't ready to die yet! Cobb's tone changes suddenly -- he questions Stump with- out guile or anger, as if his answer is obvious. COBB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But neither am I. Cobb stares at Stump, waiting for an answer, and forgets about the road. Stump looks up in fear and points at the road. STUMP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty! Cobb swerves wildly back onto the road, such as it exists in the blizzard. COBB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I'm not ready to die. STUMP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then watch the fucking road. COBB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're not listening to me! I may have every God damn disease known to man but I am never going to check into a hospital because I am alive and I am going to get laid in Reno! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) You're gonna get laid, too, Stumpy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I don't wanta get laid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You queer?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were divorced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in the middle of a... problem. We're talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talking my ass! Quit hanging on -- get a divorce. Is that why you don't wanta get laid in Reno? 'Cause you're feeling loyal to a woman you're divorcing? That's really stupid, Stumpy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not getting a divorce.    I'm being loyal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that why you used to wine and dine that little brunette who had an office across the courtyard from you in Santa Barbara?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump is nailed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about her?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do my homework, Stumpy. I know where the bodies are buried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively) It didn't last long!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey,   no need to defend yourself. When   it comes to women I'm a total shit   -- the difference is, Stumpy, that   I know I'm a shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody knows about the brunette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our little secret, huh? (beat) And that part about me being a shit with women? That ain't gonna be in the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta put your family in my book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your book?! My book! And nothing about my ex-wives or children are gonna be in it. My book is about baseball!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My book is about Cobb!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb is baseball!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly something appears ahead on the roadside. Cobb doesn't see it. Stump does. It looks like a figure, huddled, wrapped, immobile in the swirling snow. It can't be...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty!    Look!   It's a man!

dialogues.speaker: FIGURE
dialogues.text: attempts to wave at the car. A nearly-frozen, desperate attempt to flag down the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop the car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb brakes -- the car spins to a stop some distance past the figure standing knee-deep in snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever it is he's gotta be pretty stupid to be out in this shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're out in this shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Stump climbs out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump trudges back to the half-frozen figure who flails his arms stiffly at the apparition of a car in all this. The figure is wrapped in blankets, his head covered. We cannot see who it is until we are in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me.   Please help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God... it's you.     Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Willie, the black man who Cobb fired the day before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you found me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me help you to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you that you'd only last one day with the bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb's in the car. He's driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie stops trudging toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cobb's in the car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'm not getting in the car with that son of a bitch. I'd rather take my chances out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're coming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Stump drags Willie to the car, though the man is re- luctant the whole way, he is in no condition to resist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering the whole way) He hates me. He hates black people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fucking hates everybody. Don't give him the pleasure of dying out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If dying out here gives him pleasure then I won't die out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get to the car -- Stump opens the back door to help the nearly-frozen man into the car. Cobb grumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty, it's Willie. We can give him a lift to town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit! I ain't givin' no nigger a ride nowhere!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Stump loses it -- he grabs Cobb's pistol off the seat of the car and aims it right at Cobb's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up and give him a ride!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now who's the coward! You won't shoot me! You need me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump hands the gun to Willie.....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But I'm sure Willie would take great pleasure in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie climbs into the back seat with the gun.       Cobb livid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll pay for this, Stumpy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Willie, you a baseball fan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the greatest ballplayer of all time, in your opinion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie Mays, no doubt about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That nigger couldn't hold my jock!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Cobb, the man is speaking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Cobb jumps on the gas -- the car races off, back down the mountain, fishtailing as it goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'd say the second greatest player of all time is Jackie Robinson... or maybe Josh Gibson...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And of course, the greatest base runner of all time isn't riding in this car -- the fastest baseball player of all time was Cool Papa Bell -- Cool Papa would've easily broke all your stolen base records --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noooooo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool Papa   was so fast that when he entered a   hotel room and flipped the light   switch off, he'd be asleep in   bed before it got dark...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then there's Satchel Paige...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, Satchel Paige could throw a porkchop past a wolf, Mr. Cobb, ol' Satchel woulda had you eatin' outta his hand, he woulda had you hittin' .220 and kissin' his black ass to boot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut this man up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man with the gun does the talking, you wretched, old prick...

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: racing down the highway in the snow, and we go      out hearing Willie recount the greatest ballplayers      of a time -- all of them black -- as Cobb seethes, a      gun his head. Stump feeds Willie, watching Cobb's       racis simmer. Into the storm the car disappears -- fishtailing down the mountain. The blizzard grows thicker, the flurries taking over the mountain, until all we see is -- The thick snow falling from the dark sky.      Suddenly -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ice!   Slow down! Tyyyy!

dialogues.speaker: STEEP DOWNGRADE
dialogues.text: as slick as a bobsled run.

dialogues.speaker: STUMP
dialogues.text: Terror.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: Terror.   He lowers the gun and hangs on for dear life.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: He accelerates with vengeance.

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: wobbles and starts spinning -- out of control, then spinning continuous 360s down the grade.

dialogues.speaker: THREE MEN
dialogues.text: The world spins around them as they cling for their lives. Until: THUD -- the car slams into a bank of snow.      Suddenly, silence. The three men sit without speaking for several beats, slowly acknowledging that they have survived. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucked up roads. They don't build highways like they used to.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL SIGN IN DISTANCE
dialogues.text: glows a welcome sign in the night.    It is no longer snowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Cobb, thank you for a lift into town...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie hands the gun to Stump and climbs out of the car, bidding farewell to Stump as he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, sir, should leave this disgusting, wretched, sorry son of a bitch immediately. Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie tips his hat and trudges to the neon glow in the distance. Cobb and Stump alone in the car. They both look out -- the car is buried, hood deep, in the bank of snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the famous arch that reads: "The Biggest Little City in the World," a tow truck pulls Stump's car into town, and up to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck stops -- Stump helps Cobb out and into the old style building adjacent to the gaudier casinos.
