dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump helps Cobb to the registration desk in a clean, but very modest old hotel. A WOMAN, 30s, stands at the counter in the middle of some dispute with the clerk. She wears a long, cheap, plain- cloth overcoat and galoshes. Stump bursts in, oblivious to the conversation in progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two rooms, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman turns to confront the two men.     Now we see h On a fabulous platinum-blonde wig is stuck    a yellow slicker-type rain hat. The ear flaps are     awry, the platinum-blonde wig curls up around it --    the effect i thrilling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand back, you old farts. I'm in the middle of something -- (back to clerk) The heat's on the blink and the mattress is lumpy -- I want a discount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, c'mon, you always want a discount, Mona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ra-mona... and the mattress is always lumpy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb pulls out a bottle of pills and washes a handful down with a deep swig from a pint bottle of whiskey. The Clerk looks on with alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I've gotta get him checked in. He's very sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all sick in the eyes of God -- but some of us still have manners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She whirls and leaves the lobby, leaving the three men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two rooms, next to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump helps Cobb shoot up with insulin -- The needle clumsily groping for a vein in the old man's arm.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: His face looks terrible, drawn, drained. Cobb reaches into his pouch and pulls out a bundle of cash and security notes, tied neatly with a string.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely audible) My money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your money's okay, Ty, right here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My gun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your gun's okay, too... right here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Stump hands Cobb his beloved pistol, which Cobb takes with great affection and comfort. Stump helps Cobb into bed, covering him with a blanket. The gun and the money sit on the pillow next to his head. Cobb speaks with great pain just before he passes out from pain, drugs, and exhaustion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't missed the testimonial dinner, have we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No we haven't missed the dinner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb manages a small, pained smile before drifting off into sleep. Stump turns off the light and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump pours a glass of vodka, settles into a chair, and dials the phone. He swallows deeply of the drink, and waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Hello? Happy Birthday! It's your Daddy! Yeah! (beat) Your birthday was yesterday?! No, it couldn't be!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump quickly checks a calendar on the wall and realizes he's missed his son's birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Omigod, what can I say? I feel terrible -- no, it's not okay, jeez... When I get off the road we'll do something special -- a late birthday, eh? Maybe you can go to spring training or something with me, eh? Yeah... (beat) Listen, is your mother there? (beat) I know she doesn't want to speak to me, but I want to speak to her. (waits for answer) Okay, okay -- I feel terrible about the birthday... I'll call you real soon. And tell your mother I'm not drinking anymore. Okay... 'bye, 'bye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump hangs up the phone -- Takes a deep breath, and... He pours another drink, and sits down to his typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump is hunkered over his typewriter pounding away. VOICE OVER indicates what he is writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a fool for thinking Cobb's brilliance might be what I needed at this moment of my life... Ty Cobb was the last thing I needed. (beat) He was not misunderstood -- he was understood perfectly well. He hated blacks, he hated Jews, he hated Catholics -- he hated everything except himself and his own view of the world... (beat) At times it seemed like he would drop dead in front of me... (beat) ... and other times he seemed indestructible...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) I was reluctant to view the great Ty Cobb as a pathetic character, lost in the past, paranoia, and the shallow defense of 'his own breeding'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear SOUNDS of the TYPEWRITER BANGING away as... We DRIFT OUT the window -- Leaving Stump to write all night, at first viewing through the window, then moving until we have a view of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the incessant BANGING OF the TYPEWRITER GRADUALLY FADE AWAY...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump asleep -- full sun shines in the window.       Noon A BOTTLE CRASHES against the headboard jarring Stump to consciousness. He looks up to see: Cobb reading the pages in a rage.     He tears them as he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Pathetic, paranoid, lost in the past!' What is this shit?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump awakens slowly, disoriented, amidst a shattered bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are my notes!   You can't look at my notes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're notes -- my life! You're gonna betray me, you son of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want the truth?   I'm gonna tell the truth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine, for crissakes, I'm the writer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm the legend and legends are not pathetic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly defensive) These are just notes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you understand anything about 'greatness'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should find another writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not enough time left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This frank admission momentarily stops Stump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm entitled to my opinions --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's pathetic. Who gives a good God damn about the opinions of Al Stump?! What people want to know about is Ty Cobb! And they don't want to know who he hates 'cause everybody hates somebody! They don't wanta know if he had two wives or ten! They don't wanta know if he hit women or if they hit him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think they wanta know how to steal second base?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!   Precisely!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, oh, oh... I get it. You're one of them college psychology type guys. You wanta find the missing piece to finish the puzzle known as the Madman Cobb -- you think you're the next Hemingway but you're just a moderate success in a moderate-sized pond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Cobb! I'm much more than a moderate success!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it, now you're showing some life. You want psychology? I'll give you some fucking psychology!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cynically) I'm all ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father was a great man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (B&W) A horse shakes its head, attached to a buggy.     A man pats the horse and ties it to a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father told my mother he was going out of town for the weekend on business. But he didn't go. He came back 'cause he thought she was being unfaithful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 79   INT. HOUSE - NIGHT (B&W) The woman preparing for bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why he thought it -- 'cause my mother was a wonderful woman -- but he thought it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80   EXT. HOUSE - NIGHT (B&W) The father climbing up the trellis onto the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My   father thought he would catch the   man who was trying to steal his   wife from him... catch him in   the act... 81   FATHER (B&W) pulls a gun as he nears the window. INT. HOUSE - NIGHT (B&W) The woman hears noises on the balcony and leaps out of bed in terror. CLOSE ON WOMAN (B&W) She turns and looks toward the bed.   We don't see whatever she's looking at. WOMAN'S POV (B&W) The window.    It starts to open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father had high standards... the highest. He believed in quality... he believed in education... he believed in God... he believed in me... he believed in my mother... But on that night he seemed like a prowler... and so -- 82   EXT. BALCONY - NIGHT (B&W) A SHOTGUN BLAST takes out Cobb's father's stomach and he reels back onto the balcony. He rolls to his elbows and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother killed my father... shot him in the belly... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then blew his head clean off...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A SECOND SHOTGUN BLAST takes his head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb stands above Stump who is still in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that? A pretty God damn good piece of psychology, eh? That what you're looking for? The childhood incident that explans me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb spits on the papers of Stump's text.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I was a prick before it happened and a bigger prick after it happened so stick that up your Sigmund Freud ass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.   Stump is shaken by this story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother killed your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you ain't printing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if I say so. I don't think you understand something -- I have final editorial approval of the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I do.    I always have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you read your contract?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my standard contract. I just signed. I would never have agreed to this if you had final approval.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cobb calmly picks up the phone and hands it to Stump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call your agent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump quickly dials and gets an answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Charlie? Al... I'm in Reno... yeah... things are fine... (beat) Yeah, listen... I'm just checking... did we give away final editorial approval on this Cobb book? (long beat of disbelief) We did? Cobb has it? Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump listens long and hard -- his face sinks. Cobb smiles and hangs the phone back up for Stump who reaches for the bottle on the nightstand and pours himself a morning drink of vodka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you were pretty stupid to give up approval, weren't ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Cobb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck me? Why me? (suddenly charming) Why you mad at me? Your agent made the deal, your lawyer, your publisher, you didn't even read the contract because you trusted them! Who the hell ever trusted a lawyer or an agent?! If I was Al Stump, the guy I'd be pissed off at would be Al Stump!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, you son of a bitch -- if you die before the book is finished, I'll write the story I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I ain't dying first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll write slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll die slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb lights a big cigar -- and sets fire to Stump's pages. Both men watch them go up in smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now get dressed so we can go find some women...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump just stares back -- exhausted and overmatched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The main room -- Showtime.     In progress. LOUIS PRIMA WITH KEELY SMITH are thrilling a packed house full of dinner tables. LOUIS PRIMA AND GROUP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'That old black magic has me in its spell, That old black magic that you weave so well..' Cobb and Stump at a table drinking and eating. A cigarette girl works the room at a nearby table.      S all legs and fishnet stockings... and wig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look't that -- hundred bucks says I get in her pants before dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cigarette girl turns and we recognize her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God -- it's Mona... Ra-mona... We met her at the hotel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramona is a vision in this outfit as she approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramona arrives at their table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cigarettes, gentlemen? Cigars? We stockpiled some Havanas before Senor Castro did his little number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coupla Monte Cristos, Ramona, number twos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have we met?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the hotel -- checking in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohyeah, you were the asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb is suddenly gallant, gentlemanly, even charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, young lady, I must apologize for the behavior of my friend -- he has a crude side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramona delivers the cigars and collects the money. Stump is a bit chagrined and caught off guard by this Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I accept.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramona... Spanish name... lovely... it means 'moonlit garden of the gods'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually it's German and means 'wise protectoress' but thanks for the thought...

dialogues.speaker: ONSTAGE
dialogues.text: Louis Prima takes the mike -- His number has finished to much applause from the drunken crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much, you're a great crowd ... I have been informed that we have a celebrity with us tonight who is a legend, a man who truly needs no introduction...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) ... so let's give a Harrah's Casino warm welcome to the greatest baseball player of all time, the one and only Ty Cobb!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spotlight flies to Cobb who kisses Ramona's hand. Stump has been left out of the exchange, and mumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Moonlit garden of the gods'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience stands to applaud Cobb -- Full and genuine. Cobb graciously waves to the crowd, bowing, basking.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ONSTAGE
dialogues.text: motions to his band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this one's for the Georgia Peach!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They break into "Sweet Georgia Brown."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No gal made has got a shade on Sweet Georgia Brown, Two left feet but oh so sweet is Sweet Georgia Brown...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb breaks into a little dance with Ramona at the table, much to Stump's (and Ramona's) amazement. For a moment, at least, there is great footwork and lightness in his movement -- we get a glimpse of the great athlete he once was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great Ty Cobb! C'mon up here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want you, Ty --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course they want me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Cobb heads for the stage, walking better but not without effort, a walk enhanced by drugs and booze. As he does, Ramona turns to Stump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The greatest baseball player of all time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know baseball from shmaseball but I know a nice man when I see one and I also know it's time for my coffee break. Hasta luego.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she's off with her trayful of tobacco to the cocktail lounge.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ONSTAGE
dialogues.text: As Cobb arrives...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Fellas, she can't get, are fellas, she ain't met, Georgia made her, Georgia claimed her, Sweet Georgia Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis Prima welcomes Cobb to the mike to thunderous applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My great pleasure, sir -- (shaking hands) I've always wanted to ask you something, Mr. Cobb, with all the great ballplayers playing right now -- how well do you think you'd do against today's players?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I figure against today's pitchers I'd only hit about .275,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's amazing, Mr. Cobb, considering your lifetime average is nearly a hundred points higher. Why do you think you'd only hit .275 against today's pitchers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm 72 fucking years old, that's why, God damn it. Give me that thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb grabs the mike and takes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all I wanta thank you for that song, 'Sweet Georgia Brown... it's a great song about my home state and I appreciate it... (beat) That song has become the theme song for the Harlem Globetrotters... (as Prima nods with a smile) It's too bad such a fine song had to be stole by a buncha niggers playing a faggot game in their underwear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prima and his cohorts are aghast. They cling to the hope that this is some put-on, some joke. They force a small, unnatural laugh. Stump winces and leaves the room, heading for the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course the Globetrotters are owned by a Jew named Saperstein so whadda you expect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A disaster.     Prima tries gamely to seize the mike back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. Another round of applause for the Georgia Peach, Ty Cobb!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the mike, Dago -- gimme a God damn minute. Nobody's got respect for their elders any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb turns to the crowd which, even in it's drunken state is appalled and in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let me explain to you how to hit a baseball. It's a lost art. Ever since that half-nigger Ruth started hitting home runs, the skill, the art, and the science have been lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb grabs a clarinet from a member of Prima's band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, say this is a bat...

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: The CASINO MANAGERS and SECURITY FORCES are quickly gathering to figure out what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just haul him off --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Ty Cobb! He'll fucking kill me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, the bat is like a wand, a magic wand... it should be caressed, held like a woman... like a woman who's really in need of a man...

dialogues.speaker: OFFSTAGE
dialogues.text: The Casino Manager winces and consults.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, here we go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitting a baseball is really very easy... you can't force it... you can't overpower it... you go with the pitch... you let the bat do the work... it's all rhythm and flow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Cobb starts demonstrating hitting techniques to the bewildered audience and casino staff. He strikes that familiar, strange stance -- choked up on the bat, a split grip, the bat held parallel to the ground...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump sees Ramona at the bar, her cigarette/cigar tray on the bar. She's smoking and working her way through a tall drink. He approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You again? You could learn some manners from your friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try harder. (motions for bartender)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a beautiful woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the wig. Ramona pulls the wig off her head revealing a sea of bobby pins and hair pins tying her natural brown hair to her head. She sets the wig on the counter and scratches her natural scalp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The damn thing itches but it's good for tips. Give me a scratch, will ya? Stump scratches the back of her scalp, somewhat embar- rassed and somewhat aroused. RAMON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn you on? Hey, Harvey, another round. On him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vodka and grapefruit juice. Ramona slaps the wig back on her head. Slightly akilter. She doesn't care. Harvey delivers another round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wig's crooked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it bother you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no... I was just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bored, shrugging) You wanta go to bed with me, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump is so taken aback that he doesn't know how to answer. Flustered, he looks around, then takes a deep hit on his drink. He is very unsure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a whore! I don't screw for money?! Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I didn't know.     I mean I'm not good at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just divorced, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's written all over ya.    Giant letters right across the forehead. D-I-V-O-R-C-E.     Ha! Plain as day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramona lets out a loud, hearty laugh without inhibition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's obvious, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obvious. (beat) So, if ya wanta pay me to screw, I won't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw or pay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whichever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So ya don't wanta screw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this ambiguity -- I see why she's divorcing ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump, completely befuddled, lets down completely. He doesn't care about getting laid or drunk or anything for the moment, except having someone to talk to -- the some- one is Ramona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what I'm saying or doing anymore... I'm trying to speak my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told my wife I wanted a divorce. She said 'okay' -- then I realized maybe I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then go back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then quit crying. You want a divorce, you don't want a divorce, you're asking marital advice from a woman you're trying to get in the sack -- Jeez Louise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sigh.   Stump is lost.    He motions to the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another round, Harvey. (back to Ramona) This assignment has me befuddled. I'm supposed to tell the world that a monster is really a prince. I'm supposed to lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You being paid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it's not a lie. It's a job. Quit agonizing -- take the money, do what you gotta do, and get it over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For godsakes why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump has to think about this for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows greatness. I'm in the presence of greatness. I want to learn about greatness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him like he's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greatness is overrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're right, maybe you're right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump drinks deeply -- his heart needs alcoholic reinforcement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be in someone's arms tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh that. Why do men have such a hard time saying what they want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump and Ramona stagger in drunkenly -- they are awkward and passionate. She grabs his vodka and takes a swig from the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, wait... don't drink too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya think I won't be able to screw if I'm too drunk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screwed, stewed, and tattooed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs a hearty laugh, letting it all out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mere... I want to hold you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so thoughtful -- the others are trying to get me drunk and you're trying to keep me sober.  You'd be good husband material.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so fast --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They embrace -- and hold each other fully, doing nothing but holding on. Stump relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a whore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh, shh... I know, I know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment of quiet, simple bliss -- when: The door bursts open -- the LOCK SPLINTERS with a CRASH, and: Cobb bursts into the room -- Full of rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two-timing bastard! You God damn Judas Iscariot! You stealing my girl! I'll kill you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not 'your' girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Cobb lashes out at Stump -- Stump tries to block the blow, but Cobb is relentless, and Cobb hits him again. Stump falls backwards -- His head hits a corner of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Cobb backhands Ramona across the face, knocking her down. Stump lies on the floor only half conscious. He grabs his head. Blood. The room swirls in front of him as -- Cobb grabs Ramona, pulling his everpresent gun from his pocket as he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're coming with me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb jams the pistol into her jaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dizzying view of Cobb dragging the woman out of his room. And he passes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb throws Ramona to the floor and locks the door.     H wig falls off. Cobb picks it up and stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does -- The wig sits at a funny angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the Georgia Peach. I have 4,191 base hits in 11,429 at- bats, 920 stolen bases, 2,244 runs scored, and 92 batting records... (beat) And I want you to undress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb clicks the hammer of his gun with icy calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That don't scare me 'cause if you kill me I'll be dead and you ain't gonna screw a dead lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She stares at the madman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right.    You might.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your clothes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramona removes her top -- her breasts are jammed into a classic 50's push-up bra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got big tits. I like big tits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified) They aren't so big. They're average, actually -- but these bras are great. Push 'em right up there. I owe a lot to the bras and wigs. A girl needs what she needs --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.    Take it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does.    And covers her breasts with her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shy, huh?    Get on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramona gets on the bed -- Cobb circles the bed continuously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a beauty. Roll over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rolls on her face, propping herself on her elbows.

dialogues.speaker: HER FACE
dialogues.text: Terror and tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cobb, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: His eyes are full of fury and lust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I coulda done with you in my prime...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want from me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roll over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrified, she does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to do exactly what I say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH the open door -- Stump rises to his feet, feels his head, and groggily staggers out. Blood on his hand. Stump feels his way past a couple doors, listening in, unsure which room is Cobb's until a booming voice --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ramona!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump hurries to Cobb's door and listens in to be sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb stands above her with his gun and his money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly what I say...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cobb pulls a stack of bills from his bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand dollars...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out the money for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what you gotta do and get it over with, Mr. Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Cobb takes a big, sloppy hit from a bottle, throwing in a few pills for good measure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to tell everyone you meet that you fucked me and I was the best fuck you ever had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a thousand bucks?    Hell yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches out and straightens her wig which is pretty crooked by now. She lets him. Then he falls apart, vio- lently grabbing his crotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking at the most beautiful woman in the world, do you hear me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb grabs his crotch with the violence he does everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm dead down here! Dead! Nothing! And it's been like that for over two years! Nothing! Now get outta here before I hit you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb lashes out at Ramona -- a vicious right hand. ducks as his fist slams through the headboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgia Peach my ass -- Georgia trash is what you are!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ramona grabs her clothes and runs from the room, past Stump who has heard it all. He enters Cobb's room. Cobb sits at the foot of the bed, thoroughly flustered. Stump helps him into his bed where he curls up with his money and his gun, barely conscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was a great piece of ass, Stumpy, best I ever had...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have we missed the Testimonial Dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No we haven't, Ty... now get some sleep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump tucks Cobb in his bed as the old man drifts into sleep, turns off the light, and heads back to his own roo

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: asleep. Even in sleep, dying, he is twitching and full of fragments of unspent energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slept for days. I thought he was gone for sure. But even in sleep he was restless and in motion, a fire always burning in his belly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump at the typewriter, pounding away without interruption.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this time I was working on two manuscripts -- one was his version, My Life In Baseball -- which for better or worse was a history of how to steal second base or how to hit the breaking ball to the opposite field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It contained nothing about his parents, much less the death of his father at the hands of his mother...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb tossing and turning in his sleep, squeezing a pillow or blanket in a death grip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It contained nothing about his children and ex-wives, none of whom would even speak to him... (beat) It contained no insights from his friends because I couldn't find any.

dialogues.speaker: TYPEWRITER
dialogues.text: Pages of the baseball book in progress next to a neatly- stacked manuscript in progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a baseball book and I kept it in the typewriter for him to discover and amend... (beat) It was a book I never planned to publish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump sits on his bed smoking his pipe and writing in longhand on pieces of paper of all sizes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second version, my version, was written on legal pads and hotel stationery and cocktail napkins and anything I could scrape together without drawing his attention... (beat) I kept my version in a box at the bottom of my suitcase --

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Stump packs "his" version into a box, hiding it deep in his suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole thing had become an agonizing death watch, and most days I couldn't believe the son of a bitch wouldn't die...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door flies open and Cobb bursts in -- full of vim and vigor, a fresh set of clothes on, fire in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing like a cigarette girl and thirty hours of sleep to invigorate a man, Stumpy! You look like shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been writing, Ty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb goes straight for the typewriter and yanks out a page, grabbing the stack of typed pages as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well let's see how we're doing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb reads the pages with utter seriousness.       Stump watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, God damn it, Stumpy, yes! Now you're getting it! None of this Sigmund Freud bullshit! Baseball, Stumpy, baseball! Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb rushes to Stump and embraces him, almost like a child. His eyes are wet with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand! People are no damn good but you're different! You're okay, Stumpy, you get it! (beat) And I can trust you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump stares back.    And nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's go roll us some dice, Alimony, I feel a hot hand coming on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb and Stump approach the gaming tables and as they do, Cobb is recognized and approached for autographs. He signs as he walks, suddenly gracious in this moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'see how it    works, Stumpy... they boo ya your    whole career, then when you're    about to kiss off, they put ya    on a pedestal. That's what being a    legend's all about. Arriving at a craps table, Cobb barges right in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send the dice to the Peach, boys, and belly up to the bar... The croupier pushes the dice to Cobb who places a bet, as do the others. Cobb rolls the dice -- but he sees something.     Somebod

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stumpy, what is that?!

dialogues.speaker: RAMONA AND WILLIE
dialogues.text: are rolling dice at a nearby table. They appear friendly, not intimate, two among twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My girl went for the nigger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they're just next to each other by accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona!   You with that nigger! Cobb's voice silences the tables.    Ramona looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie!     Is she with you?!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ramona seizes the moment and kisses Willie on the cheek, draping herself all around him as if they were close. The intention is strictly to get back at Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my man, Mr. Cobb, and he's all man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My girl with my nigger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not your girl and he's not your --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb pulls his gun and tries to climb across the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cobb!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb on the table with a gun as Stump and police officers scramble to grab his gun hand. Customers hit the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the world coming to?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLAM, BLAM, BLAM -- the gun is FIRED REPEATEDLY into the ceiling fixtures, into the mirrors above the tables. Cobb is wrestled to the table by several men, including Stump. And it takes all of them to escort the struggling Cobb out of the casino into the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to security men) We're leaving, we're leaving! There's no reason to press charges!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to everbody) Do you know who I am?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a crazy old fool, that's who you are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back off, God damn it!   We're leaving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where we going, Stumpy, I wanta find us some more women!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump hesitates, chaos swirls around them. Cobb is out of control, we hear threats of arrest -- when...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty, Ty, Ty, calm down. It's time for the testimonial dinner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This stops Cobb cold.    He's immediately sober.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump's car passes under the arch, heading out of town, and we go to voice over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually the testimonial dinner at the Hall of Fame was still weeks away, but it was the only thing that got him calmed down enough to get us out of town without getting thrown in jail -- or getting somebody killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car takes Stump and Cobb eastward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as we headed across country, Cobb as usual was oblivious to the chaos he'd left in his wake. In fact he was buoyed with new enthusiasm at the prospects of seeing his cronies once again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb is in an upbeat mood. He's reading a map.       A ta recorder with hand mike sits between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know something, Alimony, I believe you're the best friend I ever had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swear on a Bible, Stumpy -- I feel I can trust you now.

dialogues.speaker: STUMP
dialogues.text: deeply alarmed by this confession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was disturbed, to say the least, that he felt we were friends -- but at least for the moment it made things bearable. (beat) And he started talking -- the world according to Ty Cobb...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb talks into a tape recorder sitting on his lap, enjoying the hand microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into recorder) And then this fat ass named Babe Ruth came into the league and damn near destroyed the game of baseball... We all thought he was gonna eat and fuck his way outta the league but he hung around for a few years --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Hung around'? He was -- (quickly revising) -- next to you -- the greatest player of all time. He hit 714 home runs?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody can hit home runs. Now excuse me, I got work to do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Ty --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Cobb resumes into the tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't care that they cheered and adored Ruth -- I cared that they respected his ballplaying -- Christ, they built Yankee Stadium for him with a 297-foot right field line. My sister Florence could hit the ball 297 feet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 97    EXT. STADIUM - DAY (1920S) (B&W) Game in progress -- Detroit vs. New York. Cobb at the plate -- a pitch at his head knocks him down. Immediately, both benches clear in a major brawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whenever we got into a fight with the New Yorkers, 24 of our guys would fight 24 of their guys and me and Ruth would take on each other!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the benches clear -- Cobb races not at the pitcher but straight to right field where The Babe is charging in like a rhino straight for Cobb. Somewhere near second base the two giants collide in a thunderous smash, falling to the ground in a brawl, as 48 players slug it out in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car races into the sunset, Cobb babbling on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the day, we worked on his version of the story. At night I worked on mine...

dialogues.speaker: STUMP
dialogues.text: alone in a room, is writing on pads of paper.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He pours another drink and lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was drinking like a fish, smoking cigarettes again, and now lying about the hidden manuscript. (beat) And by writing two versions without telling him, I was becoming something Cobb was not. (beat) I was becoming a liar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An O.S. RUMBLE -- Stump quickly hides the manuscript as: Cobb thunders in with the typewritten version, the ver- sion written for Cobb's approval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fabulous stuff, Stumpy, just brilliant. You're a genius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Ty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love reading about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb takes a swig of booze. Some routine outside noise drifts in, young people LAUGHING and CARRYING ON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, who's out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb hurries outside, drawing his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb charges outside -- FIRING his PISTOL into the air. The manager and a security guard hurry over. Followed quickly by Stump, who's now an expert at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shot up his share of motels for all the usual reasons -- guests were too noisy, he couldn't get any sleep, it didn't matter -- he was always boiling over...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Stump leads Cobb back inside and calms the locals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and I became expert at keeping the peace wherever we went...

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: as Stump helps him shoot up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I also became expert at finding his veins... (beat) Which always revived him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car is parked by the side of the   highway. Cobb stands with the tape recorder next to   an endless plain flat desert or rolling farmland. The    hood is up on the car, steam spills from the radiator.    And Cobb is dicta ing like Marc Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into recorder) ... by the age of 25 I was a millionaire, by the age of 30 a multi-millionaire, by the age of 35...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump wades up in the weeds to give Cobb his pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump driving as Cobb babbles away into the tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere along the way I'd gone from biographer to stenographer to chauffeur to nurse... I was the only thing keeping the bastard alive... and I kept hoping he'd die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, Stumpy, with a friend like you, I just might go on forever...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb grabs the recorder mike and launches in again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back into the mike) Where were we -- ohyeah -- then, at the age of 42, I batted .323 which was an embarrassment to me but would be a career for anyone else...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until, by the grace of God, we arrived -- days, weeks, months later, I don't know -- in Cooperstown, New York, for his beloved testimonial dinner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ball field -- No game.    Nearby, a set of buildings. The Baseball Hall of Fame.    Stump's car pulls into town

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A classic 50's motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump and Cobb get dressed for the testimonial dinner. A black-tie affair, Stump has to help Cobb finish dressing. Cobb is full of boyish enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna meet great athletes, great warriors, great men at this Hall of Fame dinner, Stumpy. None of this modern, pansy bullshit --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been looking forward to this for a long time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fucking liar. You've been hoping I'd die first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got me wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got you right. But it's okay 'cause I need your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump squirms.      A KNOCK at the door.    Stump answers A beat-up 70-YEAR-OLD MAN stands there -- looking like a lost bum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Mickey Cochrane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.   Ty, it's Mickey Cochrane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump lets Cochrane in the door.     Ty stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your tux?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sent you money for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't arrive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You drank it, you mean. You can't go to the Hall of Fame like that. I won't allow it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things have been rough, Ty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's two things a man should never do -- complain or explain. (beat) Now go buy a God damn tux!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb peels some cash from his roll of dough and throws it at Cochrane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stores are closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding) How could you be so good behind the plate and so bad everywhere else!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb grabs the phone and dials impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Operator? What's the best men's shop in town. Who owns it? Jack who? Gimme his home number. Better yet, ring him up for me. (beat) Jack?! This is Ty Cobb. Go down to your shop and open it up and sell a tux to the great Mickey Cochrane. And sell him a cumberbund and a shirt and a bow tie and some God damn cologne. He smells like shit. What's the address? (makes a note) He'll be there in twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb thrusts the card into Cochrane's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it, Mickey, ya gotta give a better effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Ty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Cochrane exits, leaving Cobb with Stump once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lost, Stumpy, the poor man's been lost ever since he took a fastball in the ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take care of him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For years -- but that ain't goin' in the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Ty, why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it would embarrass him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb winces as he tries to rise, almost falling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanta take the cane tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to have your cane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to have anything -- if you stay near me... in case I wobble or something... just a firm hand right here... (touches his own lower back) That'll keep me upright. I'd appreciate it. Now how do I look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb poses in his tux -- proudly, unsurely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like the greatest ballplayer of all time. You going to be okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be okay when I hear the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd of locals has gathered and is cheering as the great old warriors of baseball get out of one limo after another and pass a phalanx of security guards, television cameras, and photogaphers. A P.A. ANNOUNCER presents each one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great left-handed pitcher from the New York Giants, who struck out five men in a row in the 19-- All-Star game -- Carl Hubbell. Lanky Carl Hubbell, 50's, waves to the crowd and cameras as he enters to applause from the locals gathered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great third baseman from the Chicago Cubs, Harold Joseph 'Pie' Traynor... Pie Traynor, 60's, struggles to the entrance using a cane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Lloyd Waner, the Waner brothers -- Big Poison and Little Poison -- from the Pittsburgh Pirates... The Waner Brothers, 60's, jauntily wave and enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty-eight home runs in a season -- Mr. Double-X -- the great Jimmy Foxx! The barrel-chested Jimmy Foxx, 60, gets out and waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ladies and gentlemen, the highest lifetime batting average of all time, first man elected to the Hall of Fame, retired with over 90 batting records, the one and only Georgia Peach, Ty Cobb! Cobb gets out, followed by Stump. Cobb walks into the building, past the cameras, utterly erect and upright, stretching his full six feet one inch. The applause is the most enthusiastic yet.

dialogues.speaker: COBB'S FACE
dialogues.text: His concentration is intense, his focus is mesmerizing, full of pride and rage. He makes it to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your hand, Stumpy, your hand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump slips his hand to Cobb's lower back just as they arrive at the door, and the two men enter together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, my friend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Cobb is met by the Hall of Fame director, CHARLES, 50, who shakes his hand and shows him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Cobb, good to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they head inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An orchestra is playing "Georgia On My Mind" as Cobb holds court at his table of honor. The great old players keep coming up to him, renewing old acquaintances. The first is WAHOO SAM CRAWFORD, 80's, a contemporary and at one time both teammate and adversary of young Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam Crawford, Ty, Long time no see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you, Sam.   You doin' okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm alive, Ty, I'm alive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys'll get together later and have a little party, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be some parties tonight, Peach...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROGERS HORNSBY, 60's, moves in as Wahoo Sam Crawford moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stumpy, meet Rogers Hornsby, next to me the greatest hitter of all time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How d'ya do.   You're looking good, Ty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I look like shit and you know it. We'll have a real smoker later, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohyeah... we'll tear it up good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The EMCEE raps a fork on a glass, bringing the dinner to order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to Cooperstown, ladies and gentlemen. We're here to acknowledge the greatest ballplayers of all time, those men still gracing our presence who were among the earliest inductees into the Hall of Fame. (beat) Waner, Hubbell, Foxx, Cochrane, Hornsby, Traynor -- these are the giants, the Old Masters of our craft...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spotlight moves around the room and each man waves, half rising from his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the greatest of all is with us tonight -- simply put, the best ballplayer ever -- Tyrus Raymond Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spotlight hits Cobb, who rises and waves to the crowd as the lights dim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have gathered from the archives some film on Mr. Cobb... lights, please...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The lights dim -- a giant screen is lowered, and the screen fills with old black and white footage of Cobb in action. 111   FILM (B&W) With the familiar voice of a NARRATOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This rare footage of Ty Cobb reflects his love of children, and they admired him by the thousands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FILM - COBB (B&W) posing with kids in uniforms. He clowns with them, tousling their hair, knocking off their caps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On another occasion he partakes in a Donkey Baseball game, showing his not-so-well-known lighter side...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FILM - COBB (B&W) on a donkey in a Donkey Baseball game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here's Cobb with two other immortals, Babe Ruth and Tris Speaker...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FILM - COBB, RUTH AND SPEAKER (B&W) pose on the dugout steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb and Speaker were great friends off the field, and of course were accused of fixing some games by pitcher Dutch Leonard...

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: watching the film -- He can't believe what he's seeing and hearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 113   COBB'S POV - FILM (B&W) Cobb and Speaker carousing with obvious gambler types. (NOTE: Cobb's POV of the film is subjective and dif- ferentiated from the film everyone else is seeing. We, the audience, see both versions.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb and Speaker were clearly involved with unsavory gamblers, but finally were acquitted by Judge Landis, though many questions remain unanswered --

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: leans over to Stump with grave concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is this?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a great film --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and Speaker and the fix?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think the medication's getting to you, Ty -- I'm watching you run the bases. 115   STUMP'S POV (B&W) Cobb on the basepaths rounding second and heading for third where he slides, spikes high, safe.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: Staring at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb's unique batting style led to an unprecedented 12 batting championships and a lifetime average of .367 which places him far above the field... 117   FILM - COBB (B&W) at bat, demonstrating his unique stroke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His ruthless competitive spirit has sometimes been called psychopathic...

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: turns to Stump again.    Something is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al, what are you seeing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your batting stroke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 119   COBB'S POV - FILM - COBB IN UNIFORM (B&W) climbs into the stands and starts attacking a heckler with his fists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In an infamous incident on August xx, 19xx, Cobb attacked a heckler who turned out to have no arms or legs, and was briefly suspended for the incident...

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: stands up next to Stump, who pulls him back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stumpy, what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty, I think you're not well -- I'll take you back to the motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you seeing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Connie Mack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 121   FILM - COBB (B&W) in his A's uniform poses with Connie Mack.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: settles back down and says nothing the rest of the film, though he continues to see different images.

dialogues.speaker: STUMP
dialogues.text: Enamored of the old footage. 123   STUMP'S POV - FILM (B&W) Cobb running and sliding with abandon and disregard, a fabulous athlete.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: Silently watching, disturbed. 125   COBB'S POV (B&W) He strikes his wife and she falls to the floor.    He stands over her defiantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb and his friends were notorious for booze and sex parties they had in the off-season, parties they called 'Smokers,' which took place in various hunting cabins they would fill with hookers... COBB'S POV - NAKED STRIPPER (B&W) on a table gyrates to a room so thick with smoke that Cobb and his cronies are barely visible sitting around the room, a hooker on each lap, bottles of booze flowing.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: He rubs his eyes.   What is this? CLOSE ON COCHRANE, HORNSBY, WANER BROTHERS ET AL. as they watch the same film Stump is watching. 127   FILM - COBB (B&W) rounds third and slides home in a spray of dirt.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FREEZE FRAME as the Narrator wraps it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when he retired in 1929, Cobb left behind 92 batting records and a legacy of greatness that may never be approached.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: A standing ovation from the crowd as the lights come on.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: He's still disoriented by the "film" he's seen, but the applause brings him back, and -- The orchestra plays "Sweet Georgia Brown" to Cobb's raised arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb and Stump move through the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford and Foxx have something cooking in Room 212 --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over here, Ty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never partied with these boys but they had a reputation.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 212
dialogues.text: They knock.     JIMMY FOXX opens the door a crack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got some booze?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. (beat) Who's in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, Sam and Pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any women in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and Stumpy want some action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanta meet some great broads?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Jimmy Foxx opens the door letting in Cobb and Stump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wahoo Sam Crawford, PIE TRAYNOR, and Jimmy Foxx are sit- ting quietly in the room with their wives, each woman in her 60s. Cobb and Stump stand awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Ty.   You know my wife, Lillian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is Mrs. Traynor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearl, meet Ty Cobb and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al Stump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meekly) Hello, ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foxx pulls Cobb aside and whispers discreetly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hornsby's got something on the third floor -- maybe more what you're looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb and Stump hurry along looking for Hornsby's room. LOUD MUSIC and LAUGHTER spills out of the room at the end of the hall. We see a woman enter the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you're up for this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been readier!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb takes a hit on his flask and they knock at the door. Hornsby answers the door -- we can see a party behind him, full of old players, booze, cigars -- and even some women, though the whole thing is infinitely tamer than the smokers Cobb remembers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rajah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't comin' in, Ty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me!   An' Stumpy here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb starts pushing on the door.     Hornsby holds firm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a bastard and you ain't coming to our party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's in there?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and Mickey an' a coupla broads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me talk to Mickey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hornsby signals to Cochrane who comes over to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya look good in that tux, Mick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't let ya in, Ty. It's Rogers' party. I'm an invited guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it, let me in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb tries to break into the party but Hornsby rushes over and shoves the door in his face, leaving Ty and Stump alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Presidents of the United States of America used to invite me to the White House to drink their Scotch and smoke their cigars and fuck their women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go to the motel, Ty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb heads down the hallway pounding on every door -- he's ready to explode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me in, God damn it! I invented this game! Let me in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go home, Ty, this isn't a good place to be...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) I fought for players' rights and salary increases and unions while all you crawled around on your knees begging massa' for bread crumbs just thankful for a job!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open up,   God damn it! Ballplayers can make   big money but they're too stupid!    You're all too stupid! The hell   with ya!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb grabs Stump and pulls his face close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me back to the Hall!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles, the Hall director, opens the door for Cobb and Stump. He clearly has been summoned in the middle of the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate your coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Mr. Cobb, no problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb is silent.     He and Stump enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The director flips on a     couple lights -- the hall is partially lit. Charles      stays in the b.g., as -- Cobb leads Stump past all the     displays, various shrines an photos and old bats and     balls and records, until -- A glass case full of Cobb's things -- his original Detroit Tiger uniform hangs there. Three of his famous "Black Betsy" bats, his glove, a couple balls, and his spikes. Cobb stands in front of the case just staring. Stump stands respectfully a few paces away. Cobb stares at his old uniform. Stump stares at Cobb. And Cobb starts crying, softly at first, then swelling until the muffled deep, convulsive sounds become more audible. He starts crying like a baby. Stump stands quietly nearby, afraid to move, until, finally:

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cobb sucks up the tears and finally turns to Stump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you see on that film tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw Ty Cobb playing baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was raised in the Baptist Church but I know that Heaven is just the ol' oskefagus -- the change-up. You swing from your ass 'cause you think life is a fastball down the middle and after your bat has crossed the plate and you're all off balance and looking stupid, the ball just kinda flutters across home, slow and juicy and hittable, and as it crosses the plate, the ball looks at you and smiles a nasty smile and laughs its way into the catcher's mitt... (beat) We don't just lose -- we're made fools of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save the romance for the book... (beat) ... and take me home to Georgia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black limo crosses the landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb reads the typed manuscript next to Stump who just stares out the window at the passing landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb parted with some of his hard- earned money and rented a limo in order to make what he called a 'grand re-entrance to his beloved home town of Royston...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb marks the margin of the manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He loved the manuscript, as well he should -- it made him out to be a saint --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb looks up from the manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greatest biography ever written --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The book, like Cobb, was almost finished. But he was dying slower than I was writing, and like everything else, he viewed it as a competition that he was not going to lose.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: Sweating, pale, hanging on.    A grim smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To me, we weren't riding to Georgia in a limo... (beat) We were riding in a hearse...

dialogues.speaker: BLACK LIMO
dialogues.text: heads into the deep South, past catfish restaurants, shanties, and Civil War battlegrounds. It looks like a hearse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "WELCOME TO GEORGIA -- 'The Peach State'" The hearse rushes into Georgia.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: staring out the window as the Georgia landscape passes.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOODEN SIGN
dialogues.text: Paint chipped and faded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here. And the fuckin' sign needs paint. The sign reads:    "WELCOME TO ROYSTON, GEORGIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large painting of Cobb rounding third is still visible, though barely, as part of the sign. The limo passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo moves slowly and ominously through the town. Old folks, black and white, sitting on chairs and benches in front of the stores, under awnings, stare at the strange sight of a limo cruising slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't exactly the 'grand re- entrance to a home town' that he talked about...

dialogues.speaker: TWO OLD BLACK MEN
dialogues.text: sitting under an awning. They point and discuss among themselves who this could be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb motions to the driver and to Stump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sister lives down this way... Turn right here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly confused) They look kinda the same...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's the last time you saw her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About fifteen years ago.     But she understands me... (points) There! No... damn....

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The limo cruises slowly through a quiet neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There!   I think...

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: like the others.

dialogues.speaker: LIMO
dialogues.text: stops nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see if it's her.   Wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump gets out of the car and heads up the walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump knocks at the door -- the door opens -- a woman in her 60s appears. It is FLORENCE COBB XXXXX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, ma'am. I'm looking for Florence Cobb --------.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have your brother in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   And he'd like to see you.

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: He can't quite see who it is from his angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wish to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a long time, he said. He's not well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have nothing to say to him, and wish to hear nothing he has to say to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know there's been problems, but the family is very important to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young man, the family he talks about never existed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He loved his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If his father, if my father, was such a great man, why did Tyrus turn out to be so evil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump hesitates.      He doesn't have a ready answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dying.   He just wants to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she politely closes the door in Stump's face. Stump turns, sees that the limo is at such a distance that Cobb couldn't possibly have seen, or heard, her. He returns to the limo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump climbs back in next to Cobb. He motions to the driver to head off -- the limo does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't your sister. The woman in the house said your sister moved a long time ago... she doesn't know where.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cocksucking liar. My sister doesn't want to see me and you're lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Stump, at last, goes off --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liar?! A cocksucking liar?! Of course I'm a liar! That's what I'm paid to do, isn't it?! Lie about Ty Cobb?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you didn't like the job, why didn't you quit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who would take care of you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me the sob-sister routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I listen to your bullshit, I interpret and shape and find words for your bullshit and you give me nothing but grief!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You love being this close to greatness!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop the car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car stops. Stump climbs out, searching for room and for air to breathe. The skies are overcast and dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump walks away from the car and from Cobb.     Some win blows, and the threat of rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you'd die!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, Stumpy, I will...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb is out of the car on his cane -- following Stump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And go to hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of lightning signals a storm in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'll do that, too. (beat) And look how convenient you've made it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look up -- The entrance to the Royston Cemetery. casually-maintained slope of several acres up a hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was your sister alright, and she didn't want anything to do with you either!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgive her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump walks into the cemetery to escape Cobb, who follows nonetheless with a cool resolution. Stump laughs at Cobb's comment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forgive her?! That's rich!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (following along) Forgiveness is crucial to human maturity and religious growth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Religious growth?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all need to forgive more, Al... you oughta try it. You're too angry. You're all pent up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm angry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the cemetery they keep walking, up a long hill full of tombstones and shrines and sprays of dead and dying flowers and gaudy plastic bouquets. Cobb following steadily along with his cane, several paces behind Stump. THUNDER shakes the ground.     And more lightning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you angry because I discovered you were a whore? Is that it, Alimony?
