dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm angry?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it the divorce?    You gotta let go of it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love her!   I don't want a divorce!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure ya do. You're just so used to accommodating people that you don't know what you want anymore. I accommodate nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump whirls near the top of the hill to face Cobb who continues making his way along, slowly and surely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have no friends!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you? Who are they?! Those drunken hacks you hang out with who all think they're gonna write the great American novel but all they're gonna ever do is bitch and moan and write lousy leads about high school football games? How about the brunette in the courtyard? Is she your friend? I heard she fucks everybody -- she must be everybody's friend!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mausoleum looms behind Stump, bigger than anything in the cemetery, classical, outsized, monumental, even elegant. One simple word is above the door, carved in granite: COBB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad we're here -- I was gonna bring you here anyway sooner or later --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump turns to see the mausoleum, and the word COBB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which Cobb of Georgia is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several beats as the men take it all in.      Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with pride) That is me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And rain suddenly falls from the skies, threatening to soak the two men. Cobb heads for the mausoleum -- Stump follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just enough room for the two men to stand. On either side of them are two crypts, enough for four burial vaults. Cobb is very calm now, and lucid. Rain falls heavily outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I die, my mother and father will be moved in here and, in time, my dear sister, Florence will join us as well. (beat) The family will be together again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump is still fuming, angry and cynical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under one roof? That's romantic! You want that in the book? Ty Cobb brings the family together at last to enter the gates of Heaven whole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mock my family -- you mock me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb grabs Stump by the throat and stares him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father was a great man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why are you such a bastard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being a bastard is a small price to pay for greatness. I, too, am a great man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother didn't kill my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb's fist clinches Stump's throat, forcing him to hear. Outside the mausoleum, RAIN pours down now, a Southern spring thunderstorm unleashing torrents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father told my mother he was leaving town for the weekend but he came back to the edge of the woods where he tied up his horse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 145   EXT. MOONLIT ROAD THROUGH SOME WOODS - NIGHT (B&amp A horse shakes its head, attached to a buggy. A man starts through the thinning woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... because my father thought my mother was being unfaithful to him... POV SHOT - GABLED HOUSE (B&W) In the window a silhouette of the woman.   She turns. dress drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. BALCONY ON HOUSE - NIGHT (B&W) The man climbs over the railing and peers in the window. He pulls a pistol from his belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... he was going to catch my mother with another man... 146   POV SHOT - WOMAN (B&W) Young, thin, beautiful.   She turns and looks towards a bed we cannot see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. BEDROOM - NIGHT (B&W) The woman whirls -- She hears a noise.   She ducks down. She reaches under the bed and pulls out a shotgun. She lifts the shotgun up awkwardly and without familiarity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stood by my mother when she was tried for murder a few months later. I said she was noble and true and loved my father completely and the whole thing was an accident and she was acquitted as she should have been...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: His mother looks away at something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because my mother did not kill my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His mother hands the shotgun to a naked man climbing from bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother's lover killed my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb's father raises the winow -- KABLAM! The lover FIRES into his stomach. Cobb's father lurches onto his back. CLOSE ON COBB'S FATHER (B&W) on his back staring up at his mother's lover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last thing my father saw was the face of the man fucking his wife!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lover unloads the second shell -- blowing his head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain pours down on the cemetery. THUNDER. Lightning. Cobb still holds Stump by the throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?! Is that what you want?! 'Cause that's all I know and the only other people who know about it are dead! But it ain't going in the book, either, 'cause you're the only friend I got left, and you're the only man I can trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb lets Stump go, relaxing his grip and -- Stump rages back outside into the rain.       Cobb stays dry in the doorway of the mausoleum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be your friend! I don't want to feel sorry for you! So your mother's lover blew your father's head off! I don't care. You were a prick before it happened, you were a prick after it happened, you've been a prick ever since, and you're a prick now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb quietly takes a hit on his flask from the doorway of the mausoleum, watching Stump rant and rave in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Public relations are overrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell're you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb holds out his flask for Stump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck the drink!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb motions for the limo to pull up the slope towards them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too angry, Al, you just gotta learn to let it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump stands in the rain screaming at Cobb who stands out of the rain, calm, centered, drinking, dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna tell the truth about you, Cobb! I'm gonna tell the world you hate women, Jews, and niggers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) You shouldn't use the word 'nigger', Stumpy, it's racist and demeaning. And I don't hate women -- I'm just not very good with 'em, which puts me in the same boat with you and every other man I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You treat people like dirt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb comes out into the rain toward Stump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children of America need heroes, Al, you know that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb takes him by the arm and tries to lead him to the limo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your hands off me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Al... (taking by the arm) You're making a fool of yourself out here. It's not dignified... (helpfully) Come in out of the rain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Cobb helps Stump into the limo, which pulls out of the cemetery still being drenched by rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain is thick -- Yet another motel, another neon sign, and the limo parked in front of one of the cabins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both men are sitting in rocking chairs in front of a fireplace. Stump is in a bathrobe, his feet in a big pan of warm water, a bottle of booze in his hand. He looks a mess. Cobb is idly playing with his pistol. He's calm, introspective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an educated man... tell me what you think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump just sits there, drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either my father was... inadequate ... for my mother... he was not the man I thought he was... not a great man... not even a good man... (beat) ... or my mother was... trash... a common whore... (beat) It's that simple, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump just shrugs and takes another hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a boy I stood in court next to her because suddenly I was the man of the house but as I stood there steadfastly by her side and heard the jury say 'not guilty' I knew she'd been with another man the night of the killing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump drinks deeply once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man must defend his mother at all times, isn't that right, Al? Or am I a fool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man must defend his mother at all times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I thought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the two men sit there silently, rocking slightly, trying to stay warm, when there is -- Suddenly a KNOCK at the door -- They stare at each other. Cobb puts down the gun, struggles to the door and answers it. A MAN stands in the rain, carrying a briefcase, trying vainly to keep dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al Stump?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In here.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cobb lets the man inside -- points to Stump in the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Al Stump?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump nods as he swigs on the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been chasing you all over the country -- (opens his briefcase) -- I'm here to serve you papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it's divorce, Stumpy. I know this routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're being sued for divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my wife and I are still talking?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and what she's saying is 'fuck you.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck me? Well fuck her.     No, fuck him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump reaches for the gun and aims it at the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't serving me no papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man is frozen with terror as Stump rises from the chair -- drunk and crazed, aiming the shaky gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just doing a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all loved our wives, Al, that's got nothing to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll find somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a million broads out there, Stumpy -- put down the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KABLAM! Stump FIRES at the man but the shot goes wild. He's drunk, he's not experienced with guns, he's shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not going to accommodate this man, Tyrus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all mixed up.   Give me the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're absolutely right, Tyrus, I've been accommodating people my whole life and it stops right here. (beat) You've killed a man. I'll kill a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KABLAM!   KABLAM!   He misses again. The Man drops to his knees, begging for his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Please, dear God! I have a family, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me that sob-sister stuff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump tries to hold the gun with two hands, approaching the man, to nearly point-blank range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al... no... Al... Al...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump looks crazed, a bathrobe falling open, his feet bare and wet, his hair awry from the rainstorm. He aims the gun at the man's head, looks at Cobb with wild glee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life is too short to be diplomatic. A man's friends don't care what he says or does. You're my friend, Ty, right? You're my friend!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump pulls the TRIGGER -- CLICK.     Empty. As the Man looks up, realizing he's alive, Stump strikes him across the face with the gun, drawing blood. The Man scrambles to his feet and races from the room, grabbing his briefcase, and running to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy! No wonder she wants to divorce you! You're crazy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the Man runs into the rainy night, leaving Cobb and Stump. Stump's head collapses in his hands -- Bewildered, exhausted. The two men sit alone for several beats before Stump speaks. He is completely lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I almost killed a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little drunken excess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I put a gun to a man's head and pulled the trigger. I wanted to kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's forgotten already. I saw nothing. Nothing happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al, listen to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I was hired to write a biography of the greatest sportswriter of our time -- a biography of Al Stump -- would I include what happened tonight? Attorneys are pigs -- divorce attorneys are lower than pigs. What happened tonight was private. An intimacy. Your own business. Our own business. Nobody else's. It wouldn't belong in a book about greatness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's gonna write my biography.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when the brunette in the courtyard brushed against you, I know what happened, Al. A warm summer breeze, the smell of jasmine, her black hair against a white blouse -- you came to life again, you got hard -- and when you saw her naked it was more than you could bear... it's okay, Al, it's okay... (beat) The brunette ain't gonna be in the book either...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump looks up at Cobb but says nothing. He picks up a nearly-empty bottle off the floor and takes a hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the drinking? Well, they used to say ol' Ty had a drinking problem but you can booze me right under the table right now... no problem... and nobody's God damn business, either...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump raises his hand, motioning Cobb to stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get it... I get it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment.    A look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then get some sleep.   You look pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Stump crawls on the bed toward the pillows with the stupid grace of a drunk looking for a key under the mat. Cobb helps Stump lie down, pulling a blanket over him. Stump rolls over to go to sleep, Cobb tucks the blanket around him, and picks up the bottle from the pillow. Cobb takes a last hit of the bottle -- Finishing it off. He throws it to the ground, and looks around the room for another.

dialogues.speaker: STUMP'S SUITCASE
dialogues.text: lies open on a chair.   A nearly-full bottle of Scotch is visible.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: He makes it to the bottle -- Steadies himself -- he's ex- hausted. He takes a deep swig from the Scotch. Several deep gulps, enough to kill a horse, but it only helps him steady himself. And he sees something in the suitcase -- He looks down at --

dialogues.speaker: CARDBOARD BOX
dialogues.text: which Stump has been filling with his secret manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Cobb opens the box and pulls out a paper.   He reads it. He looks at Stump, and -- Cobb takes the box and the bottle to the chair by the fireplace, where he sits down, puts on his reading glasses, and starts reading "the real story."

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: He reads page one slowly and carefully, then starts mov- ing through the box full of odd sizes of paper, hotel stationery, cocktail napkins, legal pads, all handwritten in secret. He keeps glancing up at the bed where Stump is in the deep stupor of sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading to himself) ... 'vicious, pathological, bubbling with violence... Cobb's demons were not merely exorcized on the baseball field... they spilled over into all parts of his miserable life...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 150   SERIES OF IMAGES (B&W) from the text -- from Cobb's real life. A)   Cobb sharpens his spikes with a file. B)   Cobb steals second base and slides spikes high, drawing blood. C)   Cobb driving a fancy car with a pretty woman at his side. D)   Cobb beats a man to death in an alley. E)   Cobb onstage with a stripper at a smoker. F)   Cobb striking his wife and knocking her to the ground. G)   Cobb FIRING a GUN at Stump in the hunting lodge. H)   Cobb and Stump being turned away from the parties by Hornsby. I)   Cobb's father being blown away by the shotgun. J)   Cobb on third being booed -- More trash on the field. Police restrain the crowd. Cobb stands defiantly, waving the crowd away in a menacing gesture, fearlessly. The sounds of derisive booing build to a crescendo, and then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb's eyes flare -- He's in a rage.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He rises from the chair, his adrenaline has momentarily overwhelmed his system and he moves as a young man. Cobb picks up the pistol and reloads it. Cobb marches resolutely to the bed. Cobb aims the loaded gun at Stump's sleeping head.

dialogues.speaker: STUMP
dialogues.text: Oblivious in a drunken sleep.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: Rage is in his eyes.       He cocks the gun.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: He's crying.    He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have a point of view, Stumpy, you ain't worth killing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb puts the gun into his own mouth -- He clears his throat, as if to make room for the gun barrel. He gags slightly and closes his eyes, he thinks for the last time.

dialogues.speaker: HIS FACE
dialogues.text: Something's not right. Cobb removes the gun momentarily and looks at it. He sees that the gun barrel is covered with blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God...

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: rushes into the bathroom and faces the mirror.      Blood gushes from his mouth as he coughs again.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: as he stares into the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... no... no... this can't be... Absolutely not... This is not right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb coughs again -- More blood covers his chin. He touches his chin, touches the blood, smears it around a little, looks at his hands now covered with blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified) Stumpy?! No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb moves around the tiny bathroom like a caged animal. He falls to his knees in prayer in front of the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Father, which art in heaven, hallowed by Thy name. Thy kingdom come, Thy will be done, on Earth as it is in heaven. Give us this day our daily bread, and forgive us our trespasses, as we forgive -- (beat) Aw, fuck it... little late for that sob sister stuff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb rises to his feet and looks in the mirror again. He grabs a hand towel and daubs his face with it. A bit more blood trickles from his mouth. And gradually a deep calm seems to settle over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... so this is what it feels like...

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: returns to the bedroom and sits down on the edge of the bed, next to Stump who continues his deep, drunken sleep. Cobb picks up the phone and dials as he continues mopping his chin with the towel. He speaks with great calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Can you get me the Emory Hospital? (couple beats) Hello, Ma'am? This is Ty Cobb. Can you please prepare your finest room for me? Tomorrow morning would be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb hangs up and leans back on the bed next to Stump who is still deep in drunken sleep. One man sleeps deeply, the other just sits there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limousine pulls away from the motel.      The rain ha stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump rolls over -- The hangover is brutal. He looks worse than we've ever seen him. He reaches for the bottle. Empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty. (off no answer) Tyrus. (off no answer) Peach...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump struggles to his elbow to find Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: COBB'S BED
dialogues.text: is empty and still neatly made.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Stump sits up with a start. He is suddenly, by circum- stance, awake and alert, though he looks like hell. He's also alarmed -- something is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump leaps out of bed and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three holes of broken plaster and mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: He rushes to the fireplace where only embers now glow. He sees something --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "real" manuscript scattered around the floor near the chair. Nearby, the bathroom door is open. Stump hurries into the bathroom and stops cold. Blood is on the sink and on the towels. A note is on the mirror. He pulls the note down and reads it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Dear Alimony, you lying S.O.B. -- I'm checking myself into the hospital. I think the end is near. Your Pal, Ty.'

dialogues.speaker: STUMP
dialogues.text: Deeply alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab pulls up -- Stump gets out. He's cleaned up now, shaved, dressed neatly. He enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump goes up to a reception desk and introduces himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here to see...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A CRASHING NOISE and shouting erupt from down the hall. A tray of food is thrown out into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the hell outta here! You call this a hospital?! You call this food?! You know who I am?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Mr. Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful. He's got a gun and we haven't been able to get it away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump hurries down the hall to the source of the noise. A small group of doctors, orderlies and NURSES are gathered outside Cobb's door, afraid to enter. Also there are two civilians in business suits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't want visitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump ignores the advice and enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb sits in bed -- His gun and his money are next to him. He's giving orders, ranting and raving in a classic Cobb rage. A bottle hangs from a pole, feeding his arm. A doctor and two Nurses are present, trying to deal with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Stumpy, where you been? You can't believe the shit they call food in this joint. You get some sleep? Good. I had quite a read last night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Nurse enters warily, but determined, with a small sy- ringe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir, but I need to draw some more blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put a bucket under my chin and I'll cough up a couple pints for ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to do it this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well don't poke around too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his arm for her.    She begins drawing blood

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a nice piece of ass, eh, Stumpy? (to Nurse) You come back later and climb on the big fella?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's against regulations, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you read the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, God damn it, I thought I could trust you -- I used to be able to figure out people better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That book is the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a God damn romantic! The truth is a whore! Just like you and just like my mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another NURSE enters and announces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Mr. Barton is here to see you. He says he's the chairman of the board of Coca Cola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the son of a bitch to go downstairs and have a Pepsi -- I got no time for business.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nurse #1 tapes Cobb's arm and escapes with the blood sample. A YOUNG DOCTOR enters, also warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to take your blood pressure, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's high.   What else you need to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young doctor wraps Cobb's arm with the device and begins pumping. Another OLDER DOCTOR enters and addresses Cobb head on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cobb. We cannot allow you to have a gun in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb picks up the gun and aims it at the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come and get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Older Doctor turns and leaves.        Stump enjoys th show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, Stumpy, my oldest son was a doctor -- a hacksaw artist, that's all they are -- (increasing rage) He died of a brain tumor when he was forty -- hadn't spoke to me in fifteen years 'cause I was such a rotten father -- put that in your God damn book!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Younger Doctor completes his task and slips away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Younger Doctor) Bad, ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know which version of your life I'm going to publish. I really don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There ya go again! Accommodating me and you don't have to! I died faster than you could write!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb waves his gun just as some more doctors enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the hell outta here! Everybody but Stumpy! Out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room clears -- leaving only Cobb and Stump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fooled me, Stumpy, nobody ever fooled me but you pulled it off! I thought we were pals!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know what I was getting into with this job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit explaining yourself! Stand by your convictions! You beat the great Ty Cobb! I respect that! But if you print it -- print it all! (beat) My second son weighed 300 pounds and he died of a heart attack in the arms of a hooker in Paso Robles. My other son I lost all track of and my two daughters won't speak to me and my two ex- wives won't and my siter you know won't! Print it all! (beat) And Ty Cobb can't get it up anymore! Print that too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all... confusing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not! It's simple! You won! Tell the world that the greatest ballplayer who ever lived was also the biggest bastard! Who cares now?! I give you permission and my blessing! From here on it's your story!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump nods and pulls a pint of whiskey from his coat pocket. He goes up to Cobb and tucks the whiskey under the blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a little something might help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb nods in appreciation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here, Peach... next to your gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb grabs Stump's hand for one last word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stumpy, there's nothing wrong with wanting glory. (beat) Now get the hell outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump places Cobb's hand on his money, nods, and -- Stump leaves the room without looking back at --

dialogues.speaker: COBB IN BED
dialogues.text: with a gun -- in the last stages of life, his health in total collapse, he is in complete control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctors, nurses, orderlies, men in suits -- all are waiting nervously outside the door as Stump emerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the gun? Did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, I didn't get the gun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Stump leaves the hospital, passing the Coke Executive. As he does he looks back over his shoulder to see: POV SHOT - DOCTORS, ET AL. rushing back into Cobb's room.    And -- The sounds of CRASHING, BROKEN GLASS, and COBB'S thunderous VOICE. Stump smiles slightly and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A teenage boy re-paints the faded sign that reads "Home of Ty Cobb". The luster returns to the old sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave a few bucks to a local kid to re-paint the sign, and disappeared for a while to finish the manuscripts... (beat) And wait for Cobb to die... (beat) And while I waited, Ernest Hemingway blew his brains out, Getty bought Honolulu Oil Company, and the brunette in the courtyard ran away with a handsome young lawyer...

dialogues.speaker: SIGN
dialogues.text: As Cobb's image rounding third reappears in all its former glory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on July 17, 1961... Ty Cobb died quietly in his sleep. I don't believe it was quiet, nothing he did was quiet, but that's what the newspaper writer said who wrote the lead and we all know that writers never lie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN OVER ACROSS the sign -- to the adjacent cemetery as -- A hearse enters the cemetery grounds followed by three cars. A very humble ceremony. And the voice of a country gospel singer can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'There is a fountain filled with blood, Drawn from Emmanuel's veins...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mausoleum -- The coffin sits by the open crypt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody hired a singer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'And sinners plunged beneath that flood, Lose all their guilty stains...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but it was the grimmest damn funeral service I'd ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump stands in the distance, at the back of the cemetery watching the simple, empty service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He left all his money to his family, though no members of it managed to attend the funeral, and with the rest he founded a hospital in his own name and an educational trust fund for poor Georgia children.

dialogues.speaker: THREE OLD MEN
dialogues.text: in dark suits drop flowers on the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only three ballplayers attended the service -- three oldtimers who he'd been supporting financially for many years, a fact he didn't want made public.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BUS
dialogues.text: pulls in and unloads -- Dozens of Little Leaguers in uniform join in the service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody rounded up some Little Leaguers, probably so the press photographers would have some sob sister photos... the sort Cobb hated... except the press didn't bother coming. (beat) I'll give him this -- the family was under one roof again.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Stump turns and slips quietly out of the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called my publisher. The book was ready. Only I didn't know which one to turn in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The regulars are still there, still drinking, still griping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... so a woman goes into a bar with a duck under her arm, sits down next to a drunk who looks up and says, 'Where'd you find that pig?' An' the woman says 'That's no pig, that's a duck.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' the drunk says, 'I know, I was talking to the duck.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bored laughter and another hit on their everpresent drinks. And Stump enters for the first time in nearly a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump enters comfortably, happy to see his cronies at last. Frank and the others come over from the bar, quickly gathering around Stump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stranger!   Another round on me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump settles in at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long time no see, etc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you guys... how's it goin'? Alan, how's that novel coming? Must be about done by now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, actually, I haven't started it yet... been kinda busy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all been busy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know how it is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We read that Cobb died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... finally gave up the ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?   What was he like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were the stories true or were they exaggerated?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The drinks arrive. Stump plays with his, swirling the drink around the ice with his finger, considering his answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us the truth, man, was he a monster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or was he just one of the guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump looks at the faces of his buddies, eagerly awaiting his judgement as if it is final wisdom.      He stirs his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohyeah, the absolute truth, no bullshit, give it to us straight, etc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump takes a drink and looks his friends in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A prince and a great man has fallen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murmurs of deep satisfaction from the Cronies. Affirmation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, awright, we knew it... etc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helluva guy, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A helluva guy, a great man, a misunderstood artist, a fierce competitor but a sweet man at heart... a gentle soul...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stump starts lying to his enraptured audience, we PULL BACK AND UP, going FROM the intimate center of the table TO a cool distance, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some kids play baseball with a taped-up ball, patched up bat, no uniforms, rocks for bases. The right way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I published the lie and put the truth in a closet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN OVER TO the Royston Cemetery in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: MAUSOLEUM
dialogues.text: Nearby, two holes in the earth have been opened up and the caskets of Cobb's mother and father are being moved into the mausoleum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cobb and his father and mother were together at last... (beat) The man had some deep, unexpressed sorrow that I could never know. I embraced him and I hated him... (beat) And I knew I would never write a novel, unless you considered 'Cobb' a work of fiction -- which I did not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stump walks from the dugout to the field. He stares up at the magnificent old structure, the overhanging right field facade, the great upper deck, almost a century of baseball has been played there. Cobb's palace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friends were thrilled to hear that the Georgia Peach was a helluva guy -- it excused their own failures -- if Cobb was okay, then by God, they were okay... (beat) But finally I didn't lie for them, or the children of America, or somesuch hogwash -- finally I lied for myself. (beat) I needed Cobb to be somebody he was not. I needed him to be a hero. It is my weakness.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Stump turns to walk off the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The book was a moderate success...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The empty stadium, cavernous, half cathedral, half factory... Fritz Kreisler's VIOLIN MUSIC that Cobb adored drifts up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 165   SHOTS OF COBB IN ACTION (B&W) His demon fury gives way to the fierce joy of his play- ing. He slashes a ball up the alley, turns first and never hesitates at second, and as the relay comes into third -- Cobb slides with spikes high and a cloud of dust. FREEZE FRAME.
